function.description: Returns the #GdkSurface where the drag originates.
function.return: The #GdkSurface where the drag originates

function.name: gdk_drag_set_hotspot
function.description: Sets the position of the drag surface that will be kept under the cursor hotspot. Initially, the hotspot is at the top left corner of the drag surface.

parameter.name: hot_x
parameter.parameter_description: x coordinate of the drag surface hotspot

parameter.name: hot_y
parameter.parameter_description: y coordinate of the drag surface hotspot

function.name: gdk_drag_surface_present
function.description: Present @drag_surface.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained drag_surface width to layout

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained drag_surface height to layout

function.return: %FALSE if it failed to be presented, otherwise %TRUE.

function.name: gdk_draw_context_begin_frame
function.description:
Indicates that you are beginning the process of redrawing @region on the @context's surface.
Calling this function begins a drawing operation using @context on the surface that @context was created from. The actual requirements and guarantees for the drawing operation vary for different implementations of drawing, so a #GdkCairoContext and a #GdkGLContext need to be treated differently.
A call to this function is a requirement for drawing and must be followed by a call to gdk_draw_context_end_frame(), which will complete the drawing operation and ensure the contents become visible on screen.
Note that the @region passed to this function is the minimum region that needs to be drawn and depending on implementation, windowing system and hardware in use, it might be necessary to draw a larger region. Drawing implementation must use gdk_draw_context_get_frame_region() to query the region that must be drawn.
When using GTK+, the widget system automatically places calls to gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() and gdk_draw_context_end_frame() via the use of #GskRenderers, so application code does not need to call these functions explicitly.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the context used to draw the frame

parameter.name: region
parameter.parameter_description: minimum region that should be drawn

function.name: gdk_draw_context_end_frame
function.description:
Ends a drawing operation started with gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() and makes the drawing available on screen. See that function for more details about drawing.
When using a #GdkGLContext, this function may call `glFlush()` implicitly before returning; it is not recommended to call `glFlush()` explicitly before calling this function.

function.name: gdk_draw_context_get_display
function.description: Retrieves the #GdkDisplay the @context is created for
function.return: a #GdkDisplay or %NULL

function.name: gdk_draw_context_get_frame_region
function.description:
Retrieves the region that is currently in the process of being repainted.
After a call to gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() this function will return a union of the region passed to that function and the area of the surface that the @context determined needs to be repainted.
If @context is not inbetween calls to gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() and gdk_draw_context_end_frame(), %NULL will be returned.
function.return: a Cairo region or %NULL if not drawing a frame.

function.name: gdk_draw_context_get_surface
function.description: Retrieves the #GdkSurface used by the @context.
function.return: a #GdkSurface or %NULL

function.name: gdk_draw_context_is_in_frame
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @context is in the process of drawing to its surface after a call to gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() and not yet having called gdk_draw_context_end_frame(). In this situation, drawing commands may be effecting the contents of a @context's surface.
function.return: %TRUE if the context is between gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() and gdk_draw_context_end_frame() calls.

function.name: gdk_drop_finish
function.description:
Ends the drag operation after a drop.
The @action must be a single action selected from the actions available via gdk_drop_get_actions().

parameter.name: action
parameter.parameter_description: the action performed by the destination or 0 if the drop failed

function.name: gdk_drop_get_actions
function.description:
Returns the possible actions for this #GdkDrop. If this value contains multiple actions - ie gdk_drag_action_is_unique() returns %FALSE for the result - gdk_drop_finish() must choose the action to use when accepting the drop. This will only happen if you passed %GDK_ACTION_ASK as one of the possible actions in gdk_drag_status(). %GDK_ACTION_ASK itself will not be included in the actions returned by this function.
This value may change over the lifetime of the #GdkDrop both as a response to source side actions as well as to calls to gdk_drop_status() or gdk_drop_finish(). The source side will not change this value anymore once a drop has started.
function.return: The possible #GdkDragActions

function.name: gdk_drop_get_device
function.description: Returns the #GdkDevice performing the drop.
function.return: The #GdkDevice performing the drop.

function.name: gdk_drop_get_display
function.description: Gets the #GdkDisplay that @self was created for.
function.return: a #GdkDisplay

function.name: gdk_drop_get_drag
function.description:
If this is an in-app drag-and-drop operation, returns the #GdkDrag that corresponds to this drop.
If it is not, %NULL is returned.
function.return: the corresponding #GdkDrag

function.name: gdk_drop_get_formats
function.description: Returns the #GdkContentFormats that the drop offers the data to be read in.
function.return: The possible #GdkContentFormats

function.name: gdk_drop_get_surface
function.description: Returns the #GdkSurface performing the drop.
function.return: The #GdkSurface performing the drop.

function.name: gdk_drop_read_async
function.description: Asynchronously read the dropped data from a #GdkDrop in a format that complies with one of the mime types.

parameter.name: mime_types
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to an array of mime types

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the io priority for the read operation

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

function.name: gdk_drop_read_finish
function.description: Finishes an async drop read operation, see gdk_drop_read_async().

parameter.name: out_mime_type
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the used mime type

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure, or %NULL

function.return: the #GInputStream, or %NULL

function.name: gdk_drop_read_value_async
function.description:
Asynchronously request the drag operation's contents converted to the given @type. When the operation is finished @callback will be called. You can then call gdk_drop_read_value_finish() to get the resulting #GValue.
For local drag'n'drop operations that are available in the given #GType, the value will be copied directly. Otherwise, GDK will try to use gdk_content_deserialize_async() to convert the data.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: callback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: gdk_drop_read_value_finish
function.description: Finishes an async drop read started with gdk_drop_read_value_async().

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a #GError location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore.

function.return: a #GValue containing the result.

function.name: gdk_drop_status
function.description:
Selects all actions that are potentially supported by the destination.
When calling this function, do not restrict the passed in actions to the ones provided by gdk_drop_get_actions(). Those actions may change in the future, even depending on the actions you provide here.
The @preferred action is a hint to the drag'n'drop mechanism about which action to use when multiple actions are possible.
This function should be called by drag destinations in response to %GDK_DRAG_ENTER or %GDK_DRAG_MOTION events. If the destination does not yet know the exact actions it supports, it should set any possible actions first and then later call this function again.

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: Supported actions of the destination, or 0 to indicate that a drop will not be accepted

parameter.name: preferred
parameter.parameter_description: A unique action that's a member of @actions indicating the preferred action.

function.name: gdk_event_get_axes
function.description: Extracts all axis values from an event.

parameter.name: axes
parameter.parameter_description: the array of values for all axes

function.return: %TRUE on success, otherwise %FALSE

function.name: gdk_event_get_axis
function.description: Extract the axis value for a particular axis use from an event structure.

parameter.name: axis_use
parameter.parameter_description: the axis use to look for

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the value found

function.return: %TRUE if the specified axis was found, otherwise %FALSE

function.name: gdk_event_get_device
function.description: Returns the device of an event.
function.return: a #GdkDevice.

function.name: gdk_event_get_device_tool
function.description:
If the event was generated by a device that supports different tools (eg. a tablet), this function will return a #GdkDeviceTool representing the tool that caused the event. Otherwise, %NULL will be returned.
Note: the #GdkDeviceTools will be constant during the application lifetime, if settings must be stored persistently across runs, see gdk_device_tool_get_serial()
function.return: The current device tool, or %NULL

function.name: gdk_event_get_display
function.description: Retrieves the #GdkDisplay associated to the @event.
function.return: a #GdkDisplay

function.name: gdk_event_get_event_sequence
function.description: If @event is a touch event, returns the #GdkEventSequence to which the event belongs. Otherwise, return %NULL.
function.return: the event sequence that the event belongs to

function.name: gdk_event_get_event_type
function.description: Retrieves the type of the event.
function.return: a #GdkEventType

function.name: gdk_event_get_modifier_state
function.description: Returns the modifier state field of an event.
function.return: the modifier state of @event

function.name: gdk_event_get_pointer_emulated
function.description: Returns whether this event is an 'emulated' pointer event (typically from a touch event), as opposed to a real one.
function.return: %TRUE if this event is emulated

function.name: gdk_event_get_position
function.description: Extract the event surface relative x/y coordinates from an event.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: location to put event surface x coordinate

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: location to put event surface y coordinate

function.name: gdk_event_get_source_device
function.description:
This function returns the hardware (slave) #GdkDevice that has triggered the event, falling back to the virtual (master) device (as in gdk_event_get_device()) if the event wasn’t caused by interaction with a hardware device. This may happen for example in synthesized crossing events after a #GdkSurface updates its geometry or a grab is acquired/released.
If the event does not contain a device field, this function will return %NULL.
function.return: a #GdkDevice, or %NULL.

function.name: gdk_event_get_surface
function.description: Extracts the #GdkSurface associated with an event.
function.return: The #GdkSurface associated with the event

function.name: gdk_event_get_time
function.description: Returns the time stamp from @event, if there is one; otherwise returns #GDK_CURRENT_TIME.
function.return: time stamp field from @event

function.name: gdk_event_ref
function.description: Increase the ref count of @event.
function.return: @event

function.name: gdk_event_triggers_context_menu
function.description:
This function returns whether a #GdkEventButton should trigger a context menu, according to platform conventions. The right mouse button always triggers context menus.
This function should always be used instead of simply checking for event->button == %GDK_BUTTON_SECONDARY.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkEvent, currently only button events are meaningful values

function.return: %TRUE if the event should trigger a context menu.

function.name: gdk_event_unref
function.description: Decrease the ref count of @event, and free it if the last reference is dropped.

function.name: gdk_events_get_angle
function.description: If both events contain X/Y information, this function will return %TRUE and return in @angle the relative angle from @event1 to @event2. The rotation direction for positive angles is from the positive X axis towards the positive Y axis.

parameter.name: angle
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the relative angle between both events

function.return: %TRUE if the angle could be calculated.

function.name: gdk_events_get_center
function.description: If both events contain X/Y information, the center of both coordinates will be returned in @x and @y.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the X coordinate of the center

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the Y coordinate of the center

function.return: %TRUE if the center could be calculated.

function.name: gdk_events_get_distance
function.description: If both events have X/Y information, the distance between both coordinates (as in a straight line going from @event1 to @event2) will be returned.
function.return: %TRUE if the distance could be calculated.

function.name: gdk_focus_event_get_in
function.description: Extracts whether this event is about focus entering or leaving the surface.
function.return: %TRUE of the focus is entering

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_begin_updating
function.description: Starts updates for an animation. Until a matching call to gdk_frame_clock_end_updating() is made, the frame clock will continually request a new frame with the %GDK_FRAME_CLOCK_PHASE_UPDATE phase. This function may be called multiple times and frames will be requested until gdk_frame_clock_end_updating() is called the same number of times.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_end_updating
function.description: Stops updates for an animation. See the documentation for gdk_frame_clock_begin_updating().

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_current_timings
function.description: Gets the frame timings for the current frame.
function.return: the #GdkFrameTimings for the frame currently being processed, or even no frame is being processed, for the previous frame. Before any frames have been processed, returns %NULL.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_frame_counter
function.description: A #GdkFrameClock maintains a 64-bit counter that increments for each frame drawn.
function.return: inside frame processing, the value of the frame counter for the current frame. Outside of frame processing, the frame counter for the last frame.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_frame_time
function.description: Gets the time that should currently be used for animations. Inside the processing of a frame, it’s the time used to compute the animation position of everything in a frame. Outside of a frame, it's the time of the conceptual “previous frame,” which may be either the actual previous frame time, or if that’s too old, an updated time.
function.return: a timestamp in microseconds, in the timescale of of g_get_monotonic_time().

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_history_start
function.description: #GdkFrameClock internally keeps a history of #GdkFrameTimings objects for recent frames that can be retrieved with gdk_frame_clock_get_timings(). The set of stored frames is the set from the counter values given by gdk_frame_clock_get_history_start() and gdk_frame_clock_get_frame_counter(), inclusive.
function.return: the frame counter value for the oldest frame that is available in the internal frame history of the #GdkFrameClock.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_refresh_info
function.description: Using the frame history stored in the frame clock, finds the last known presentation time and refresh interval, and assuming that presentation times are separated by the refresh interval, predicts a presentation time that is a multiple of the refresh interval after the last presentation time, and later than @base_time.

parameter.name: base_time
parameter.parameter_description: base time for determining a presentaton time

parameter.name: refresh_interval_return
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store the determined refresh interval, or %NULL. A default refresh interval of 1/60th of a second will be stored if no history is present.

parameter.name: presentation_time_return
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store the next candidate presentation time after the given base time. 0 will be will be stored if no history is present.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_timings
function.description: Retrieves a #GdkFrameTimings object holding timing information for the current frame or a recent frame. The #GdkFrameTimings object may not yet be complete: see gdk_frame_timings_get_complete().

parameter.name: frame_counter
parameter.parameter_description: the frame counter value identifying the frame to be received.

function.return: the #GdkFrameTimings object for the specified frame, or %NULL if it is not available. See gdk_frame_clock_get_history_start().

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_request_phase
function.description: Asks the frame clock to run a particular phase. The signal corresponding the requested phase will be emitted the next time the frame clock processes. Multiple calls to gdk_frame_clock_request_phase() will be combined together and only one frame processed. If you are displaying animated content and want to continually request the %GDK_FRAME_CLOCK_PHASE_UPDATE phase for a period of time, you should use gdk_frame_clock_begin_updating() instead, since this allows GTK to adjust system parameters to get maximally smooth animations.

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_complete
function.description: The timing information in a #GdkFrameTimings is filled in incrementally as the frame as drawn and passed off to the window system for processing and display to the user. The accessor functions for #GdkFrameTimings can return 0 to indicate an unavailable value for two reasons: either because the information is not yet available, or because it isn't available at all. Once gdk_frame_timings_get_complete() returns %TRUE for a frame, you can be certain that no further values will become available and be stored in the #GdkFrameTimings.
function.return: %TRUE if all information that will be available for the frame has been filled in.

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_frame_counter
function.description: Gets the frame counter value of the #GdkFrameClock when this this frame was drawn.
function.return: the frame counter value for this frame

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_frame_time
function.description: Returns the frame time for the frame. This is the time value that is typically used to time animations for the frame. See gdk_frame_clock_get_frame_time().
function.return: the frame time for the frame, in the timescale of g_get_monotonic_time()

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_predicted_presentation_time
function.description: Gets the predicted time at which this frame will be displayed. Although no predicted time may be available, if one is available, it will be available while the frame is being generated, in contrast to gdk_frame_timings_get_presentation_time(), which is only available after the frame has been presented. In general, if you are simply animating, you should use gdk_frame_clock_get_frame_time() rather than this function, but this function is useful for applications that want exact control over latency. For example, a movie player may want this information for Audio/Video synchronization.
function.return: The predicted time at which the frame will be presented, in the timescale of g_get_monotonic_time(), or 0 if no predicted presentation time is available.

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_presentation_time
function.description: Reurns the presentation time. This is the time at which the frame became visible to the user.
function.return: the time the frame was displayed to the user, in the timescale of g_get_monotonic_time(), or 0 if no presentation time is available. See gdk_frame_timings_get_complete()

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_refresh_interval
function.description: Gets the natural interval between presentation times for the display that this frame was displayed on. Frame presentation usually happens during the “vertical blanking interval”.
function.return: the refresh interval of the display, in microseconds, or 0 if the refresh interval is not available. See gdk_frame_timings_get_complete().

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count of @timings.
function.return: @timings

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count of @timings. If @timings is no longer referenced, it will be freed.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_clear_current
function.description:
Clears the current #GdkGLContext.
Any OpenGL call after this function returns will be ignored until gdk_gl_context_make_current() is called.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_current
function.description: Retrieves the current #GdkGLContext.
function.return: the current #GdkGLContext, or %NULL

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_debug_enabled
function.description: Retrieves the value set using gdk_gl_context_set_debug_enabled().
function.return: %TRUE if debugging is enabled

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_display
function.description: Retrieves the #GdkDisplay the @context is created for
function.return: a #GdkDisplay or %NULL

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_forward_compatible
function.description: Retrieves the value set using gdk_gl_context_set_forward_compatible().
function.return: %TRUE if the context should be forward compatible

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_required_version
function.description: Retrieves the major and minor version requested by calling gdk_gl_context_set_required_version().

parameter.name: major
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the major version to request

parameter.name: minor
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the minor version to request

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_shared_context
function.description: Retrieves the #GdkGLContext that this @context share data with.
function.return: a #GdkGLContext or %NULL

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_surface
function.description: Retrieves the #GdkSurface used by the @context.
function.return: a #GdkSurface or %NULL

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_use_es
function.description: Checks whether the @context is using an OpenGL or OpenGL ES profile.
function.return: %TRUE if the #GdkGLContext is using an OpenGL ES profile

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_version
function.description:
Retrieves the OpenGL version of the @context.
The @context must be realized prior to calling this function.

parameter.name: major
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the major version

parameter.name: minor
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the minor version

function.name: gdk_gl_context_is_legacy
function.description:
Whether the #GdkGLContext is in legacy mode or not.
The #GdkGLContext must be realized before calling this function.
When realizing a GL context, GDK will try to use the OpenGL 3.2 core profile; this profile removes all the OpenGL API that was deprecated prior to the 3.2 version of the specification. If the realization is successful, this function will return %FALSE.
If the underlying OpenGL implementation does not support core profiles, GDK will fall back to a pre-3.2 compatibility profile, and this function will return %TRUE.
You can use the value returned by this function to decide which kind of OpenGL API to use, or whether to do extension discovery, or what kind of shader programs to load.
function.return: %TRUE if the GL context is in legacy mode

function.name: gdk_gl_context_make_current
function.description: Makes the @context the current one.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_realize
function.description:
Realizes the given #GdkGLContext.
It is safe to call this function on a realized #GdkGLContext.
function.return: %TRUE if the context is realized

function.name: gdk_gl_context_set_debug_enabled
function.description:
Sets whether the #GdkGLContext should perform extra validations and run time checking. This is useful during development, but has additional overhead.
The #GdkGLContext must not be realized or made current prior to calling this function.

parameter.name: enabled
parameter.parameter_description: whether to enable debugging in the context

function.name: gdk_gl_context_set_forward_compatible
function.description:
Sets whether the #GdkGLContext should be forward compatible.
Forward compatibile contexts must not support OpenGL functionality that has been marked as deprecated in the requested version; non-forward compatible contexts, on the other hand, must support both deprecated and non deprecated functionality.
The #GdkGLContext must not be realized or made current prior to calling this function.

parameter.name: compatible
parameter.parameter_description: whether the context should be forward compatible

function.name: gdk_gl_context_set_required_version
function.description:
Sets the major and minor version of OpenGL to request.
Setting @major and @minor to zero will use the default values.
The #GdkGLContext must not be realized or made current prior to calling this function.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_set_use_es
function.description:
Requests that GDK create an OpenGL ES context instead of an OpenGL one, if the platform and windowing system allows it.
The @context must not have been realized.
By default, GDK will attempt to automatically detect whether the underlying GL implementation is OpenGL or OpenGL ES once the @context is realized.
You should check the return value of gdk_gl_context_get_use_es() after calling gdk_gl_context_realize() to decide whether to use the OpenGL or OpenGL ES API, extensions, or shaders.

parameter.name: use_es
parameter.parameter_description: whether the context should use OpenGL ES instead of OpenGL, or -1 to allow auto-detection

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_new
function.description:
Creates a new texture for an existing GL texture.
Note that the GL texture must not be modified until @destroy is called, which will happen when the GdkTexture object is finalized, or due to an explicit call of gdk_gl_texture_release().

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the ID of a texture that was created with @context

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the nominal width of the texture

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the nominal height of the texture

parameter.name: destroy
parameter.parameter_description: a destroy notify that will be called when the GL resources are released

function.return: A newly-created #GdkTexture

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_release
function.description:
Releases the GL resources held by a #GdkGLTexture that was created with gdk_gl_texture_new().
The texture contents are still available via the gdk_texture_download() function, after this function has been called.

function.name: gdk_grab_broken_event_get_grab_surface
function.description: Extracts the grab surface from a grab broken event.
function.return: the grab surface of @event

function.name: gdk_grab_broken_event_get_implicit
function.description: Checks whether the grab broken event is for an implicit grab.
function.return: %TRUE if the an implicit grab was broken

function.name: gdk_intern_mime_type
function.description:
Canonicalizes the given mime type and interns the result.
If @string is not a valid mime type, %NULL is returned instead. See RFC 2048 for the syntax if mime types.

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: string of a potential mime type

function.return: An interned string for the canonicalized mime type or %NULL if the string wasn't a valid mime type

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_consumed_modifiers
function.description: Extracts the consumed modifiers from a key event.
function.return: the consumed modifiers or @event

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_keycode
function.description: Extracts the keycode from a key event.
function.return: the keycode of @event

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_keyval
function.description: Extracts the keyval from a key event.
function.return: the keyval of @event

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_layout
function.description: Extracts the layout from a key event.
function.return: the layout of @event

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_level
function.description: Extracts the shift level from a key event.
function.return: the shift level of @event

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_match
function.description: Gets a keyval and modifier combination that will cause gdk_key_event_matches() to successfully match the given event.
function.return: %TRUE on success

function.name: gdk_key_event_is_modifier
function.description: Extracts whether the key event is for a modifier key.
function.return: %TRUE if the @event is for a modifier key

function.name: gdk_key_event_matches
function.description:
Matches a key event against a keyboard shortcut that is specified as a keyval and modifiers. Partial matches are possible where the combination matches if the currently active group is ignored.
Note that we ignore Caps Lock for matching.
function.return: a GdkKeyMatch value describing whether @event matches

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_caps_lock_state
function.description: Returns whether the Caps Lock modifer is locked.
function.return: %TRUE if Caps Lock is on

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_direction
function.description: Returns the direction of effective layout of the keymap. The direction of a layout is the direction of the majority of its symbols. See pango_unichar_direction().
function.return: %PANGO_DIRECTION_LTR or %PANGO_DIRECTION_RTL if it can determine the direction. %PANGO_DIRECTION_NEUTRAL otherwise.

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_display
function.description: Retrieves the #GdkDisplay associated to the @keymap.
function.return: a #GdkDisplay

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_entries_for_keycode
function.description: Returns the keyvals bound to @hardware_keycode. The Nth #GdkKeymapKey in @keys is bound to the Nth keyval in @keyvals. Free the returned arrays with g_free(). When a keycode is pressed by the user, the keyval from this list of entries is selected by considering the effective keyboard group and level. See gdk_keymap_translate_keyboard_state().

parameter.name: keys
parameter.parameter_description: return location for array of #GdkKeymapKey, or %NULL

parameter.name: keyvals
parameter.parameter_description: return location for array of keyvals, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if there were any entries

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_entries_for_keyval
function.description: Obtains a list of keycode/group/level combinations that will generate @keyval. Groups and levels are two kinds of keyboard mode; in general, the level determines whether the top or bottom symbol on a key is used, and the group determines whether the left or right symbol is used. On US keyboards, the shift key changes the keyboard level, and there are no groups. A group switch key might convert a keyboard between Hebrew to English modes, for example. #GdkEventKey contains a %group field that indicates the active keyboard group. The level is computed from the modifier mask. The returned array should be freed with g_free().

parameter.name: keys
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an array of #GdkKeymapKey

parameter.name: n_keys
parameter.parameter_description: return location for number of elements in returned array

function.return: %TRUE if keys were found and returned

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_modifier_state
function.description: Returns the current modifier state.
function.return: the current modifier state.

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_num_lock_state
function.description: Returns whether the Num Lock modifer is locked.
function.return: %TRUE if Num Lock is on

function.name: gdk_keymap_get_scroll_lock_state
function.description: Returns whether the Scroll Lock modifer is locked.
function.return: %TRUE if Scroll Lock is on

function.name: gdk_keymap_have_bidi_layouts
function.description: Determines if keyboard layouts for both right-to-left and left-to-right languages are in use.
function.return: %TRUE if there are layouts in both directions, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gdk_keymap_lookup_key
function.description: Looks up the keyval mapped to a keycode/group/level triplet. If no keyval is bound to @key, returns 0. For normal user input, you want to use gdk_keymap_translate_keyboard_state() instead of this function, since the effective group/level may not be the same as the current keyboard state.

parameter.name: key
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkKeymapKey with keycode, group, and level initialized

function.return: a keyval, or 0 if none was mapped to the given @key

function.name: gdk_keymap_translate_keyboard_state
function.description:
Translates the contents of a #GdkEventKey into a keyval, effective group, and level. Modifiers that affected the translation and are thus unavailable for application use are returned in @consumed_modifiers. See [Groups][key-group-explanation] for an explanation of groups and levels. The @effective_group is the group that was actually used for the translation; some keys such as Enter are not affected by the active keyboard group. The @level is derived from @state. For convenience, #GdkEventKey already contains the translated keyval, so this function isn’t as useful as you might think.
@consumed_modifiers gives modifiers that should be masked outfrom @state when comparing this key press to a hot key. For instance, on a US keyboard, the `plus` symbol is shifted, so when comparing a key press to a `<Control>plus` accelerator `<Shift>` should be masked out.
|[<!-- language="C" --> // We want to ignore irrelevant modifiers like ScrollLock #define ALL_ACCELS_MASK (GDK_CONTROL_MASK | GDK_SHIFT_MASK | GDK_ALT_MASK) state = gdk_event_get_modifier_state (event); gdk_keymap_translate_keyboard_state (keymap, gdk_key_event_get_keycode (event), state, gdk_key_event_get_group (event), &keyval, NULL, NULL, &consumed); if (keyval == GDK_PLUS && (state & ~consumed & ALL_ACCELS_MASK) == GDK_CONTROL_MASK) // Control was pressed ]|
An older interpretation @consumed_modifiers was that it contained all modifiers that might affect the translation of the key; this allowed accelerators to be stored with irrelevant consumed modifiers, by doing: |[<!-- language="C" --> // XXX Don’t do this XXX if (keyval == accel_keyval && (state & ~consumed & ALL_ACCELS_MASK) == (accel_mods & ~consumed)) // Accelerator was pressed ]|
However, this did not work if multi-modifier combinations were used in the keymap, since, for instance, `<Control>` would be masked out even if only `<Control><Alt>` was used in the keymap. To support this usage as well as well as possible, all single modifier combinations that could affect the key for any combination of modifiers will be returned in @consumed_modifiers; multi-modifier combinations are returned only when actually found in @state. When you store accelerators, you should always store them with consumed modifiers removed. Store `<Control>plus`, not `<Control><Shift>plus`,

parameter.name: effective_group
parameter.parameter_description: return location for effective group, or %NULL

parameter.name: consumed_modifiers
parameter.parameter_description: return location for modifiers that were used to determine the group or level, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if there was a keyval bound to the keycode/state/group

function.name: gdk_keyval_convert_case
function.description: Obtains the upper- and lower-case versions of the keyval @symbol. Examples of keyvals are #GDK_KEY_a, #GDK_KEY_Enter, #GDK_KEY_F1, etc.

parameter.name: lower
parameter.parameter_description: return location for lowercase version of @symbol

parameter.name: upper
parameter.parameter_description: return location for uppercase version of @symbol

function.name: gdk_keyval_from_name
function.description:
Converts a key name to a key value.
The names are the same as those in the `gdk/gdkkeysyms.h` header file but without the leading “GDK_KEY_”.
function.return: the corresponding key value, or %GDK_KEY_VoidSymbol if the key name is not a valid key

function.name: gdk_keyval_is_lower
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the given key value is in lower case.
function.return: %TRUE if @keyval is in lower case, or if @keyval is not subject to case conversion.

function.name: gdk_keyval_is_upper
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the given key value is in upper case.
function.return: %TRUE if @keyval is in upper case, or if @keyval is not subject to case conversion.

function.name: gdk_keyval_name
function.description:
Converts a key value into a symbolic name.
The names are the same as those in the `gdk/gdkkeysyms.h` header file but without the leading “GDK_KEY_”.
function.return: a string containing the name of the key, or %NULL if @keyval is not a valid key. The string should not be modified.

function.name: gdk_keyval_to_lower
function.description: Converts a key value to lower case, if applicable.
function.return: the lower case form of @keyval, or @keyval itself if it is already in lower case or it is not subject to case conversion.

function.name: gdk_keyval_to_unicode
function.description: Convert from a GDK key symbol to the corresponding ISO10646 (Unicode) character.
function.return: the corresponding unicode character, or 0 if there is no corresponding character.

function.name: gdk_keyval_to_upper
function.description: Converts a key value to upper case, if applicable.
function.return: the upper case form of @keyval, or @keyval itself if it is already in upper case or it is not subject to case conversion.

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_new
function.description: Creates a new texture for a blob of image data. The #GBytes must contain @stride x @height pixels in the given format.
function.return: A newly-created #GdkTexture

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_connector
function.description: Gets the name of the monitor's connector, if available.
function.return: the name of the connector

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_display
function.description: Gets the display that this monitor belongs to.
function.return: the display

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_geometry
function.description: Retrieves the size and position of an individual monitor within the display coordinate space. The returned geometry is in ”application pixels”, not in ”device pixels” (see gdk_monitor_get_scale_factor()).

parameter.name: geometry
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRectangle to be filled with the monitor geometry

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_height_mm
function.description: Gets the height in millimeters of the monitor.
function.return: the physical height of the monitor

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_manufacturer
function.description:
Gets the name or PNP ID of the monitor's manufacturer, if available.
Note that this value might also vary depending on actual display backend.
PNP ID registry is located at https://uefi.org/pnp_id_list
function.return: the name of the manufacturer, or %NULL

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_model
function.description: Gets the string identifying the monitor model, if available.
function.return: the monitor model, or %NULL

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_refresh_rate
function.description:
Gets the refresh rate of the monitor, if available.
The value is in milli-Hertz, so a refresh rate of 60Hz is returned as 60000.
function.return: the refresh rate in milli-Hertz, or 0

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_scale_factor
function.description:
Gets the internal scale factor that maps from monitor coordinates to the actual device pixels. On traditional systems this is 1, but on very high density outputs this can be a higher value (often 2).
This can be used if you want to create pixel based data for a particular monitor, but most of the time you’re drawing to a surface where it is better to use gdk_surface_get_scale_factor() instead.
function.return: the scale factor

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_subpixel_layout
function.description: Gets information about the layout of red, green and blue primaries for each pixel in this monitor, if available.
function.return: the subpixel layout

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_width_mm
function.description: Gets the width in millimeters of the monitor.
function.return: the physical width of the monitor

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_workarea
function.description:
Retrieves the size and position of the “work area” on a monitor within the display coordinate space. The returned geometry is in ”application pixels”, not in ”device pixels” (see gdk_monitor_get_scale_factor()).
The work area should be considered when positioning menus and similar popups, to avoid placing them below panels, docks or other desktop components.
Note that not all backends may have a concept of workarea. This function will return the monitor geometry if a workarea is not available, or does not apply.

parameter.name: workarea
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkRectangle to be filled with the monitor workarea

function.name: gdk_monitor_is_valid
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the @monitor object corresponds to a physical monitor. The @monitor becomes invalid when the physical monitor is unplugged or removed.
function.return: %TRUE if the object corresponds to a physical monitor

function.name: gdk_motion_event_get_history
function.description: Retrieves the history of the @event motion, as a list of time and coordinates.

parameter.name: out_n_coords
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the length of the returned array

function.return: an array of time and coordinates

function.name: gdk_pad_event_get_axis_value
function.description: Extracts the information from a pad strip or ring event.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: a pad strip or ring event

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the axis index

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the axis value

function.name: gdk_pad_event_get_button
function.description: Extracts information about the pressed button from a pad event.
function.return: the button of @event

function.name: gdk_pad_event_get_group_mode
function.description: Extracts group and mode information from a pad event.

function.name: gdk_paintable_compute_concrete_size
function.description:
Applies the sizing algorithm outlined in https://drafts.csswg.org/css-images-3/#default-sizing to the given @paintable. See that link for more details.
It is not necessary to call this function when both @specified_width and @specified_height are known, but it is useful to call this function in GtkWidget:measure implementations to compute the other dimension when only one dimension is given.

parameter.name: specified_width
parameter.parameter_description: the width @paintable could be drawn into or 0.0 if unknown

parameter.name: specified_height
parameter.parameter_description: the height @paintable could be drawn into or 0.0 if unknown

parameter.name: default_width
parameter.parameter_description: the width @paintable would be drawn into if no other constraints were given

parameter.name: default_height
parameter.parameter_description: the height @paintable would be drawn into if no other constraints were given

parameter.name: concrete_width
parameter.parameter_description: will be set to the concrete width computed.

parameter.name: concrete_height
parameter.parameter_description: will be set to the concrete height computed.

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_current_image
function.description:
Gets an immutable paintable for the current contents displayed by @paintable.
This is useful when you want to retain the current state of an animation, for example to take a screenshot of a running animation.
If the @paintable is already immutable, it will return itself.
function.return: An immutable paintable for the current contents of @paintable.

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_flags
function.description:
Get flags for the paintable. This is oftentimes useful for optimizations.
See #GdkPaintableFlags for the flags and what they mean.
function.return: The #GdkPaintableFlags for this paintable.

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_intrinsic_aspect_ratio
function.description:
Gets the preferred aspect ratio the @paintable would like to be displayed at. The aspect ration is the width divided by the height, so a value of 0.5 means that the @paintable prefers to be displayed twice as high as it is wide. Consumers of this interface can use this to preserve aspect ratio when displaying this paintable.
This is a purely informational value and does not in any way limit the values that may be passed to gdk_paintable_snapshot().
Usually when a @paintable returns non-0 values from gdk_paintable_get_intrinsic_width() and gdk_paintable_get_intrinsic_height() the aspect ratio should conform to those values, though that is not required.
If the @paintable does not have a preferred aspect ratio, it returns 0.0. Negative values are never returned.
function.return: the intrinsic aspect ratio of @paintable or 0.0 if none.

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_intrinsic_height
function.description:
Gets the preferred height the @paintable would like to be displayed at. Consumers of this interface can use this to reserve enough space to draw the paintable.
This is a purely informational value and does not in any way limit the values that may be passed to gdk_paintable_snapshot().
If the @paintable does not have a preferred height, it returns 0. Negative values are never returned.
function.return: the intrinsic height of @paintable or 0 if none.

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_intrinsic_width
function.description:
Gets the preferred width the @paintable would like to be displayed at. Consumers of this interface can use this to reserve enough space to draw the paintable.
This is a purely informational value and does not in any way limit the values that may be passed to gdk_paintable_snapshot().
If the @paintable does not have a preferred width, it returns 0. Negative values are never returned.
function.return: the intrinsic width of @paintable or 0 if none.

function.name: gdk_paintable_invalidate_contents
function.description:
Called by implementations of #GdkPaintable to invalidate their contents. Unless the contents are invalidated, implementations must guarantee that multiple calls to GdkPaintable::snapshot produce the same output.
This function will emit the #GdkPaintable::invalidate-contents signal.
If a @paintable reports the %GDK_PAINTABLE_STATIC_CONTENTS flag, it must not call this function.

function.name: gdk_paintable_invalidate_size
function.description:
Called by implementations of #GdkPaintable to invalidate their size. As long as the size is not invalidated, @paintable must return the same values for its width, height and intrinsic height.
This function will emit the #GdkPaintable::invalidate-size signal.
If a @paintable reports the %GDK_PAINTABLE_STATIC_SIZE flag, it must not call this function.

function.name: gdk_paintable_new_empty
function.description: Returns a paintable that has the given intrinsic size and draws nothing. This is often useful for implementing the #GdkPaintableInterface.get_current_image() virtual function when the paintable is in an incomplete state (like a #GtkMediaStream before receiving the first frame).

parameter.name: intrinsic_width
parameter.parameter_description: The intrinsic width to report. Can be 0 for no width.

parameter.name: intrinsic_height
parameter.parameter_description: The intrinsic height to report. Can be 0 for no height.

function.return: a #GdkPaintable

function.name: gdk_paintable_snapshot
function.description: Snapshots the given paintable with the given @width and @height at the current (0,0) offset of the @snapshot. If @width and @height are not larger than zero, this function will do nothing.

function.name: gdk_pango_layout_get_clip_region
function.description:
Obtains a clip region which contains the areas where the given ranges of text would be drawn. @x_origin and @y_origin are the top left point to center the layout. @index_ranges should contain ranges of bytes in the layout’s text.
Note that the regions returned correspond to logical extents of the text ranges, not ink extents. So the drawn layout may in fact touch areas out of the clip region. The clip region is mainly useful for highlightling parts of text, such as when text is selected.

parameter.name: x_origin
parameter.parameter_description: X pixel where you intend to draw the layout with this clip

parameter.name: y_origin
parameter.parameter_description: Y pixel where you intend to draw the layout with this clip

parameter.name: index_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: array of byte indexes into the layout, where even members of array are start indexes and odd elements are end indexes

parameter.name: n_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: number of ranges in @index_ranges, i.e. half the size of @index_ranges

function.return: a clip region containing the given ranges

function.name: gdk_pango_layout_line_get_clip_region
function.description:
Obtains a clip region which contains the areas where the given ranges of text would be drawn. @x_origin and @y_origin are the top left position of the layout. @index_ranges should contain ranges of bytes in the layout’s text. The clip region will include space to the left or right of the line (to the layout bounding box) if you have indexes above or below the indexes contained inside the line. This is to draw the selection all the way to the side of the layout. However, the clip region is in line coordinates, not layout coordinates.
Note that the regions returned correspond to logical extents of the text ranges, not ink extents. So the drawn line may in fact touch areas out of the clip region. The clip region is mainly useful for highlightling parts of text, such as when text is selected.

parameter.name: x_origin
parameter.parameter_description: X pixel where you intend to draw the layout line with this clip

parameter.name: y_origin
parameter.parameter_description: baseline pixel where you intend to draw the layout line with this clip

parameter.name: index_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: array of byte indexes into the layout, where even members of array are start indexes and odd elements are end indexes

parameter.name: n_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: number of ranges in @index_ranges, i.e. half the size of @index_ranges

function.return: a clip region containing the given ranges

function.name: gdk_pipe_io_stream_new
function.description:
Creates a #GIOStream whose input- and output-stream behave like a pipe. Data written into the output stream becomes available for reading on the input stream.
Note that this is data transfer in the opposite direction to g_output_stream_splice().
function.return: a new #GIOStream

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_add_alpha
function.description:
Takes an existing pixbuf and adds an alpha channel to it. If the existing pixbuf already had an alpha channel, the channel values are copied from the original; otherwise, the alpha channel is initialized to 255 (full opacity).
If @substitute_color is %TRUE, then the color specified by (@r, @g, @b) will be assigned zero opacity. That is, if you pass (255, 255, 255) for the substitute color, all white pixels will become fully transparent.

parameter.name: substitute_color
parameter.parameter_description: Whether to set a color to zero opacity. If this is %FALSE, then the (@r, @g, @b) arguments will be ignored.

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_height
function.description: Queries the height of the bounding box of a pixbuf animation.
function.return: Height of the bounding box of the animation.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_iter
function.description:
Get an iterator for displaying an animation. The iterator provides the frames that should be displayed at a given time. It should be freed after use with g_object_unref().
@start_time would normally come from g_get_current_time(), and marks the beginning of animation playback. After creating an iterator, you should immediately display the pixbuf returned by gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf(). Then, you should install a timeout (with g_timeout_add()) or by some other mechanism ensure that you'll update the image after gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_delay_time() milliseconds. Each time the image is updated, you should reinstall the timeout with the new, possibly-changed delay time.
As a shortcut, if @start_time is %NULL, the result of g_get_current_time() will be used automatically.
To update the image (i.e. possibly change the result of gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf() to a new frame of the animation), call gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_advance().
If you're using #GdkPixbufLoader, in addition to updating the image after the delay time, you should also update it whenever you receive the area_updated signal and gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_on_currently_loading_frame() returns %TRUE. In this case, the frame currently being fed into the loader has received new data, so needs to be refreshed. The delay time for a frame may also be modified after an area_updated signal, for example if the delay time for a frame is encoded in the data after the frame itself. So your timeout should be reinstalled after any area_updated signal.
A delay time of -1 is possible, indicating "infinite."

parameter.name: start_time
parameter.parameter_description: time when the animation starts playing

function.return: an iterator to move over the animation

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_static_image
function.description: If an animation is really just a plain image (has only one frame), this function returns that image. If the animation is an animation, this function returns a reasonable thing to display as a static unanimated image, which might be the first frame, or something more sophisticated. If an animation hasn't loaded any frames yet, this function will return %NULL.
function.return: unanimated image representing the animation

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_width
function.description: Queries the width of the bounding box of a pixbuf animation.
function.return: Width of the bounding box of the animation.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_is_static_image
function.description: If you load a file with gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file() and it turns out to be a plain, unanimated image, then this function will return %TRUE. Use gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_static_image() to retrieve the image.
function.return: %TRUE if the "animation" was really just an image

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_advance
function.description:
Possibly advances an animation to a new frame. Chooses the frame based on the start time passed to gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_iter().
@current_time would normally come from g_get_current_time(), and must be greater than or equal to the time passed to gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_iter(), and must increase or remain unchanged each time gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf() is called. That is, you can't go backward in time; animations only play forward.
As a shortcut, pass %NULL for the current time and g_get_current_time() will be invoked on your behalf. So you only need to explicitly pass @current_time if you're doing something odd like playing the animation at double speed.
If this function returns %FALSE, there's no need to update the animation display, assuming the display had been rendered prior to advancing; if %TRUE, you need to call gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf() and update the display with the new pixbuf.
function.return: %TRUE if the image may need updating

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_delay_time
function.description:
Gets the number of milliseconds the current pixbuf should be displayed, or -1 if the current pixbuf should be displayed forever. g_timeout_add() conveniently takes a timeout in milliseconds, so you can use a timeout to schedule the next update.
Note that some formats, like GIF, might clamp the timeout values in the image file to avoid updates that are just too quick. The minimum timeout for GIF images is currently 20 milliseconds.
function.return: delay time in milliseconds (thousandths of a second)

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf
function.description: Gets the current pixbuf which should be displayed; the pixbuf might not be the same size as the animation itself (gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_width(), gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_height()). This pixbuf should be displayed for gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_delay_time() milliseconds. The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned pixbuf; the returned pixbuf will become invalid when the iterator advances to the next frame, which may happen anytime you call gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_advance(). Copy the pixbuf to keep it (don't just add a reference), as it may get recycled as you advance the iterator.
function.return: the pixbuf to be displayed

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_on_currently_loading_frame
function.description: Used to determine how to respond to the area_updated signal on #GdkPixbufLoader when loading an animation. area_updated is emitted for an area of the frame currently streaming in to the loader. So if you're on the currently loading frame, you need to redraw the screen for the updated area.
function.return: %TRUE if the frame we're on is partially loaded, or the last frame

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file
function.description: Creates a new animation by loading it from a file. The file format is detected automatically. If the file's format does not support multi-frame images, then an animation with a single frame will be created. Possible errors are in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR and #G_FILE_ERROR domains.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

function.return: A newly-created animation with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if any of several error conditions ocurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file_utf8
function.description: Same as gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file()

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

function.return: A newly-created animation with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if any of several error conditions ocurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_resource
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf animation by loading an image from an resource.
The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: resource_path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of the resource file

function.return: A newly-created animation, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, the image format is not supported, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, the stream contained invalid data, or the operation was cancelled.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream
function.description:
Creates a new animation by loading it from an input stream.
The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set. The @cancellable can be used to abort the operation from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned. Other possible errors are in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR and %G_IO_ERROR domains.
The stream is not closed.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GInputStream to load the pixbuf from

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, the image format is not supported, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, the stream contained invalid data, or the operation was cancelled.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream_async
function.description:
Creates a new animation by asynchronously loading an image from an input stream.
For more details see gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream(), which is the synchronous version of this function.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called in the main thread. You can then call gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GInputStream from which to load the animation

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the pixbuf is loaded

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous pixbuf animation creation operation started with gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream_async().
Since: 2.28
function.return: a #GdkPixbufAnimation or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_ref
function.description:
Adds a reference to an animation.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_ref().
function.return: The same as the @animation argument.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_unref
function.description:
Removes a reference from an animation.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_unref().

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_apply_embedded_orientation
function.description:
Takes an existing pixbuf and checks for the presence of an associated "orientation" option, which may be provided by the jpeg loader (which reads the exif orientation tag) or the tiff loader (which reads the tiff orientation tag, and compensates it for the partial transforms performed by libtiff). If an orientation option/tag is present, the appropriate transform will be performed so that the pixbuf is oriented correctly.
Since: 2.12
function.return: A newly-created pixbuf, %NULL if not enough memory could be allocated for it, or a reference to the input pixbuf (with an increased reference count).

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_clear
function.description: Resets @queue into to initial state. All buffers it contains will be released and the offset will be reset to 0.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_flush
function.description: Removes the first @n_bytes bytes from the queue.

parameter.name: n_bytes
parameter.parameter_description: amount of bytes to flush from the queue

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_get_offset
function.description: Queries the amount of bytes that has already been pulled out of @queue using functions like gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull().
function.return: Number of bytes that were already pulled from this queue.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_get_size
function.description: Returns the number of bytes currently in @queue.
function.return: amount of bytes in @queue.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_new
function.description: Creates a new empty buffer queue.
function.return: a new buffer queue. Use gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_unref () to free it.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_peek
function.description: Creates a new buffer with the first @length bytes from @queue, but unlike gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull(), does not remove them from @queue.
function.return: NULL if the requested amount of data wasn't available or a new #GBytes. Use g_bytes_unref() after use.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_peek_buffer
function.description: Gets the first buffer out of @queue and returns it. This function is equivalent to calling gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_peek() with the size of the first buffer in it.
function.return: The first buffer in @queue or %NULL if @queue is empty. Use g_bytes_unref() after use.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull
function.description: If enough data is still available in @queue, the first @length bytes are put into a new buffer and that buffer is returned. The @length bytes are removed from the head of the queue. If not enough data is available, %NULL is returned.
function.return: a new #GBytes or %NULL

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull_buffer
function.description: Pulls the first buffer out of @queue and returns it. This function is equivalent to calling gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull() with the size of the first buffer in it.
function.return: The first buffer in @queue or %NULL if @queue is empty.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_push
function.description: Appends the given @bytes to the buffers already in @queue. This function will take ownership of the given @buffer. Use g_bytes_ref () before calling this function to keep a reference.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_ref
function.description: increases the reference count of @queue by one.
function.return: The passed in @queue.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count of @queue by one. If no reference to this buffer exists anymore, the buffer and the memory it manages are freed.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_calculate_rowstride
function.description:
Calculates the rowstride that an image created with those values would have. This is useful for front-ends and backends that want to sanity check image values without needing to create them.
Since: 2.36.8

parameter.name: has_alpha
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the image should have transparency information

parameter.name: bits_per_sample
parameter.parameter_description: Number of bits per color sample

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of image in pixels, must be > 0

function.return: the rowstride for the given values, or -1 in case of error.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_composite
function.description:
Creates a transformation of the source image @src by scaling by @scale_x and @scale_y then translating by @offset_x and @offset_y. This gives an image in the coordinates of the destination pixbuf. The rectangle (@dest_x, @dest_y, @dest_width, @dest_height) is then alpha blended onto the corresponding rectangle of the original destination image.
When the destination rectangle contains parts not in the source image, the data at the edges of the source image is replicated to infinity.
![](composite.png)

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkPixbuf into which to render the results

parameter.name: dest_x
parameter.parameter_description: the left coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_y
parameter.parameter_description: the top coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_width
parameter.parameter_description: the width of the region to render

parameter.name: dest_height
parameter.parameter_description: the height of the region to render

parameter.name: offset_x
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the X direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: offset_y
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the Y direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: scale_x
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the X direction

parameter.name: scale_y
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the Y direction

parameter.name: interp_type
parameter.parameter_description: the interpolation type for the transformation.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_composite_color
function.description:
Creates a transformation of the source image @src by scaling by @scale_x and @scale_y then translating by @offset_x and @offset_y, then alpha blends the rectangle (@dest_x ,@dest_y, @dest_width, @dest_height) of the resulting image with a checkboard of the colors @color1 and @color2 and renders it onto the destination image.
If the source image has no alpha channel, and @overall_alpha is 255, a fast path is used which omits the alpha blending and just performs the scaling.
See gdk_pixbuf_composite_color_simple() for a simpler variant of this function suitable for many tasks.

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkPixbuf into which to render the results

parameter.name: dest_x
parameter.parameter_description: the left coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_y
parameter.parameter_description: the top coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_width
parameter.parameter_description: the width of the region to render

parameter.name: dest_height
parameter.parameter_description: the height of the region to render

parameter.name: offset_x
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the X direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: offset_y
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the Y direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: scale_x
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the X direction

parameter.name: scale_y
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the Y direction

parameter.name: interp_type
parameter.parameter_description: the interpolation type for the transformation.

parameter.name: check_x
parameter.parameter_description: the X offset for the checkboard (origin of checkboard is at -@check_x, -@check_y)

parameter.name: check_y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y offset for the checkboard

parameter.name: check_size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of checks in the checkboard (must be a power of two)

parameter.name: color1
parameter.parameter_description: the color of check at upper left

parameter.name: color2
parameter.parameter_description: the color of the other check

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_composite_color_simple

parameter.name: interp_type
parameter.parameter_description: the interpolation type for the transformation.

parameter.name: check_size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of checks in the checkboard (must be a power of two)

parameter.name: color1
parameter.parameter_description: the color of check at upper left

parameter.name: color2
parameter.parameter_description: the color of the other check

function.return: the new #GdkPixbuf, or %NULL if not enough memory could be allocated for it.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_copy
function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if not enough memory could be allocated.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_copy_area
function.description:
Copies a rectangular area from @src_pixbuf to @dest_pixbuf. Conversion of pixbuf formats is done automatically.
If the source rectangle overlaps the destination rectangle on the same pixbuf, it will be overwritten during the copy operation. Therefore, you can not use this function to scroll a pixbuf.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of the area to copy.

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of the area to copy.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_copy_options
function.description:
Copy the key/value pair options attached to a #GdkPixbuf to another. This is useful to keep original metadata after having manipulated a file. However be careful to remove metadata which you've already applied, such as the "orientation" option after rotating the image.
Since: 2.36
function.return: %TRUE on success.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_fill
function.description: Clears a pixbuf to the given RGBA value, converting the RGBA value into the pixbuf's pixel format. The alpha will be ignored if the pixbuf doesn't have an alpha channel.

parameter.name: pixel
parameter.parameter_description: RGBA pixel to clear to (0xffffffff is opaque white, 0x00000000 transparent black)

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_flip
function.description:
Flips a pixbuf horizontally or vertically and returns the result in a new pixbuf.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: horizontal
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to flip horizontally, %FALSE to flip vertically

function.return: the new #GdkPixbuf, or %NULL if not enough memory could be allocated for it.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_copy
function.description:
Creates a copy of @format
Since: 2.22
function.return: the newly allocated copy of a #GdkPixbufFormat. Use gdk_pixbuf_format_free() to free the resources when done

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_free
gdk_pixbuf_format_get_description
function.description:
Returns a description of the format.
Since: 2.2
function.return: a description of the format.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_get_extensions
function.description:
Returns the filename extensions typically used for files in the given format.
Since: 2.2
function.return: a %NULL-terminated array of filename extensions which must be freed with g_strfreev() when it is no longer needed.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_get_license
function.description:
Returns information about the license of the image loader for the format. The returned string should be a shorthand for a wellknown license, e.g. "LGPL", "GPL", "QPL", "GPL/QPL", or "other" to indicate some other license. This string should be freed with g_free() when it's no longer needed.
Since: 2.6
function.return: a string describing the license of @format.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_get_mime_types
function.description:
Returns the mime types supported by the format.
Since: 2.2
function.return: a %NULL-terminated array of mime types which must be freed with g_strfreev() when it is no longer needed.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_get_name
function.description:
Returns the name of the format.
Since: 2.2
function.return: the name of the format.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_is_disabled
function.description:
Returns whether this image format is disabled. See gdk_pixbuf_format_set_disabled().
Since: 2.6
function.return: whether this image format is disabled.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_is_save_option_supported
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if the save option specified by @option_key is supported when saving a pixbuf using the module implementing @format. See gdk_pixbuf_save() for more information about option keys.
Since: 2.36
function.return: %TRUE if the specified option is supported

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_is_scalable
function.description:
Returns whether this image format is scalable. If a file is in a scalable format, it is preferable to load it at the desired size, rather than loading it at the default size and scaling the resulting pixbuf to the desired size.
Since: 2.6
function.return: whether this image format is scalable.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_is_writable
function.description:
Returns whether pixbufs can be saved in the given format.
Since: 2.2
function.return: whether pixbufs can be saved in the given format.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_set_disabled
function.description:
Disables or enables an image format. If a format is disabled, gdk-pixbuf won't use the image loader for this format to load images. Applications can use this to avoid using image loaders with an inappropriate license, see gdk_pixbuf_format_get_license().
Since: 2.6

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_from_pixdata
function.description:
Converts a #GdkPixdata to a #GdkPixbuf. If @copy_pixels is %TRUE or if the pixel data is run-length-encoded, the pixel data is copied into newly-allocated memory; otherwise it is reused.
Deprecated: 2.32: Use #GResource instead.

parameter.name: copy_pixels
parameter.parameter_description: whether to copy raw pixel data; run-length encoded pixel data is always copied.

function.return: a new #GdkPixbuf.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_bits_per_sample
function.description: Queries the number of bits per color sample in a pixbuf.
function.return: Number of bits per color sample.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_byte_length
function.description:
Returns the length of the pixel data, in bytes.
Since: 2.26
function.return: The length of the pixel data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_colorspace
function.description: Queries the color space of a pixbuf.
function.return: Color space.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info
function.description:
Parses an image file far enough to determine its format and size.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: The name of the file to identify.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the width of the image, or %NULL

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the height of the image, or %NULL

function.return: A #GdkPixbufFormat describing the image format of the file or %NULL if the image format wasn't recognized. The return value is owned by #GdkPixbuf and should not be freed.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info_async
function.description:
Asynchronously parses an image file far enough to determine its format and size.
For more details see gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info(), which is the synchronous version of this function.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called in the main thread. You can then call gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: The name of the file to identify

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the file info is available

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous pixbuf parsing operation started with gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info_async().
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the width of the image, or %NULL

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the height of the image, or %NULL

function.return: A #GdkPixbufFormat describing the image format of the file or %NULL if the image format wasn't recognized. The return value is owned by GdkPixbuf and should not be freed.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_formats
function.description:
Obtains the available information about the image formats supported by GdkPixbuf.
Since: 2.2
function.return: A list of #GdkPixbufFormats describing the supported image formats. The list should be freed when it is no longer needed, but the structures themselves are owned by #GdkPixbuf and should not be freed.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_from_surface
function.description:
