Transfers image data from a #cairo_surface_t and converts it to an RGB(A) representation inside a #GdkPixbuf. This allows you to efficiently read individual pixels from cairo surfaces.
This function will create an RGB pixbuf with 8 bits per channel. The pixbuf will contain an alpha channel if the @surface contains one.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width in pixels of region to get

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height in pixels of region to get

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1, or %NULL on error

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_from_texture
function.description: Creates a new pixbuf from @texture. This should generally not be used in newly written code as later stages will almost certainly convert the pixbuf back into a texture to draw it on screen.
function.return: a new #GdkPixbuf or %NULL in case of an error

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_has_alpha
function.description: Queries whether a pixbuf has an alpha channel (opacity information).
function.return: %TRUE if it has an alpha channel, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_height
function.description: Queries the height of a pixbuf.
function.return: Height in pixels.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_n_channels
function.description: Queries the number of channels of a pixbuf.
function.return: Number of channels.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_option
function.description:
Looks up @key in the list of options that may have been attached to the @pixbuf when it was loaded, or that may have been attached by another function using gdk_pixbuf_set_option().
For instance, the ANI loader provides "Title" and "Artist" options. The ICO, XBM, and XPM loaders provide "x_hot" and "y_hot" hot-spot options for cursor definitions. The PNG loader provides the tEXt ancillary chunk key/value pairs as options. Since 2.12, the TIFF and JPEG loaders return an "orientation" option string that corresponds to the embedded TIFF/Exif orientation tag (if present). Since 2.32, the TIFF loader sets the "multipage" option string to "yes" when a multi-page TIFF is loaded. Since 2.32 the JPEG and PNG loaders set "x-dpi" and "y-dpi" if the file contains image density information in dots per inch. Since 2.36.6, the JPEG loader sets the "comment" option with the comment EXIF tag.
function.return: the value associated with @key. This is a nul-terminated string that should not be freed or %NULL if @key was not found.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_options
function.description:
Returns a #GHashTable with a list of all the options that may have been attached to the @pixbuf when it was loaded, or that may have been attached by another function using gdk_pixbuf_set_option().
See gdk_pixbuf_get_option() for more details.
Since: 2.32
function.return: a #GHashTable of key/values

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_pixels
function.description: Queries a pointer to the pixel data of a pixbuf.
function.return:
A pointer to the pixbuf's pixel data. Please see the section on [image data][image-data] for information about how the pixel data is stored in memory.
This function will cause an implicit copy of the pixbuf data if the pixbuf was created from read-only data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_pixels_with_length
function.description:
Queries a pointer to the pixel data of a pixbuf.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: The length of the binary data.

function.return:
A pointer to the pixbuf's pixel data. Please see the section on [image data][image-data] for information about how the pixel data is stored in memory.
This function will cause an implicit copy of the pixbuf data if the pixbuf was created from read-only data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_rowstride
function.description: Queries the rowstride of a pixbuf, which is the number of bytes between the start of a row and the start of the next row.
function.return: Distance between row starts.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_width
function.description: Queries the width of a pixbuf.
function.return: Width in pixels.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_init_modules
function.description:
Initalizes the gdk-pixbuf loader modules referenced by the loaders.cache file present inside that directory.
This is to be used by applications that want to ship certain loaders in a different location from the system ones.
This is needed when the OS or runtime ships a minimal number of loaders so as to reduce the potential attack surface of carefully crafted image files, especially for uncommon file types. Applications that require broader image file types coverage, such as image viewers, would be expected to ship the gdk-pixbuf modules in a separate location, bundled with the application in a separate directory from the OS or runtime- provided modules.
Since: 2.40

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: Path to directory where the loaders.cache is installed

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_close
function.description:
Informs a pixbuf loader that no further writes with gdk_pixbuf_loader_write() will occur, so that it can free its internal loading structures. Also, tries to parse any data that hasn't yet been parsed; if the remaining data is partial or corrupt, an error will be returned. If %FALSE is returned, @error will be set to an error from the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR or #G_FILE_ERROR domains. If you're just cancelling a load rather than expecting it to be finished, passing %NULL for @error to ignore it is reasonable.
Remember that this does not unref the loader, so if you plan not to use it anymore, please g_object_unref() it.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for a #GError, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: %TRUE if all image data written so far was successfully passed out via the update_area signal

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_get_animation
function.description: Queries the #GdkPixbufAnimation that a pixbuf loader is currently creating. In general it only makes sense to call this function after the "area-prepared" signal has been emitted by the loader. If the loader doesn't have enough bytes yet (hasn't emitted the "area-prepared" signal) this function will return %NULL.
function.return: The #GdkPixbufAnimation that the loader is loading, or %NULL if not enough data has been read to determine the information.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_get_format
function.description:
Obtains the available information about the format of the currently loading image file.
Since: 2.2
function.return: A #GdkPixbufFormat or %NULL. The return value is owned by GdkPixbuf and should not be freed.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_get_pixbuf
function.description: Queries the #GdkPixbuf that a pixbuf loader is currently creating. In general it only makes sense to call this function after the "area-prepared" signal has been emitted by the loader; this means that enough data has been read to know the size of the image that will be allocated. If the loader has not received enough data via gdk_pixbuf_loader_write(), then this function returns %NULL. The returned pixbuf will be the same in all future calls to the loader, so simply calling g_object_ref() should be sufficient to continue using it. Additionally, if the loader is an animation, it will return the "static image" of the animation (see gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_static_image()).
function.return: The #GdkPixbuf that the loader is creating, or %NULL if not enough data has been read to determine how to create the image buffer.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_new
function.description: Creates a new pixbuf loader object.
function.return: A newly-created pixbuf loader.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_new_with_mime_type
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf loader object that always attempts to parse image data as if it were an image of mime type @mime_type, instead of identifying the type automatically. Useful if you want an error if the image isn't the expected mime type, for loading image formats that can't be reliably identified by looking at the data, or if the user manually forces a specific mime type.
The list of supported mime types depends on what image loaders are installed, but typically "image/png", "image/jpeg", "image/gif", "image/tiff" and "image/x-xpixmap" are among the supported mime types. To obtain the full list of supported mime types, call gdk_pixbuf_format_get_mime_types() on each of the #GdkPixbufFormat structs returned by gdk_pixbuf_get_formats().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: mime_type
parameter.parameter_description: the mime type to be loaded

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an allocated #GError, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf loader.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_new_with_type
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf loader object that always attempts to parse image data as if it were an image of type @image_type, instead of identifying the type automatically. Useful if you want an error if the image isn't the expected type, for loading image formats that can't be reliably identified by looking at the data, or if the user manually forces a specific type.
The list of supported image formats depends on what image loaders are installed, but typically "png", "jpeg", "gif", "tiff" and "xpm" are among the supported formats. To obtain the full list of supported image formats, call gdk_pixbuf_format_get_name() on each of the #GdkPixbufFormat structs returned by gdk_pixbuf_get_formats().

parameter.name: image_type
parameter.parameter_description: name of the image format to be loaded with the image

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an allocated #GError, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf loader.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_set_size
function.description:
Causes the image to be scaled while it is loaded. The desired image size can be determined relative to the original size of the image by calling gdk_pixbuf_loader_set_size() from a signal handler for the ::size-prepared signal.
Attempts to set the desired image size are ignored after the emission of the ::size-prepared signal.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The desired width of the image being loaded.

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The desired height of the image being loaded.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_write
function.description: This will cause a pixbuf loader to parse the next @count bytes of an image. It will return %TRUE if the data was loaded successfully, and %FALSE if an error occurred. In the latter case, the loader will be closed, and will not accept further writes. If %FALSE is returned, @error will be set to an error from the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR or #G_FILE_ERROR domains.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: Length of the @buf buffer in bytes.

function.return: %TRUE if the write was successful, or %FALSE if the loader cannot parse the buffer.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_write_bytes
function.description:
This will cause a pixbuf loader to parse a buffer inside a #GBytes for an image. It will return %TRUE if the data was loaded successfully, and %FALSE if an error occurred. In the latter case, the loader will be closed, and will not accept further writes. If %FALSE is returned, @error will be set to an error from the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR or #G_FILE_ERROR domains.
See also: gdk_pixbuf_loader_write()
Since: 2.30
function.return: %TRUE if the write was successful, or %FALSE if the loader cannot parse the buffer.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_major_version
function.description:
The major version number of the gdk-pixbuf library. (e.g. in gdk-pixbuf version 1.2.5 this is 1.)
This variable is in the library, so represents the gdk-pixbuf library you have linked against. Contrast with the #GDK_PIXBUF_MAJOR macro, which represents the major version of the gdk-pixbuf headers you have included.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_micro_version
function.description:
The micro version number of the gdk-pixbuf library. (e.g. in gdk-pixbuf version 1.2.5 this is 5.)
This variable is in the library, so represents the gdk-pixbuf library you have linked against. Contrast with the #GDK_PIXBUF_MICRO macro, which represents the micro version of the gdk-pixbuf headers you have included.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_minor_version
function.description:
The minor version number of the gdk-pixbuf library. (e.g. in gdk-pixbuf version 1.2.5 this is 2.)
This variable is in the library, so represents the gdk-pixbuf library you have linked against. Contrast with the #GDK_PIXBUF_MINOR macro, which represents the minor version of the gdk-pixbuf headers you have included.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new

parameter.name: has_alpha
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the image should have transparency information

parameter.name: bits_per_sample
parameter.parameter_description: Number of bits per color sample

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of image in pixels, must be > 0

function.return: A newly-created #GdkPixbuf with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if not enough memory could be allocated for the image buffer.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_bytes
function.description:
Creates a new #GdkPixbuf out of in-memory readonly image data. Currently only RGB images with 8 bits per sample are supported. This is the #GBytes variant of gdk_pixbuf_new_from_data().
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: Image data in 8-bit/sample packed format inside a #GBytes

parameter.name: has_alpha
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the data has an opacity channel

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of the image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of the image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: rowstride
parameter.parameter_description: Distance in bytes between row starts

function.return: A newly-created #GdkPixbuf structure with a reference count of 1.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_data
function.description:
Creates a new #GdkPixbuf out of in-memory image data. Currently only RGB images with 8 bits per sample are supported.
Since you are providing a pre-allocated pixel buffer, you must also specify a way to free that data. This is done with a function of type #GdkPixbufDestroyNotify. When a pixbuf created with is finalized, your destroy notification function will be called, and it is its responsibility to free the pixel array.
See also gdk_pixbuf_new_from_bytes().

parameter.name: has_alpha
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the data has an opacity channel

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of the image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of the image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: rowstride
parameter.parameter_description: Distance in bytes between row starts

parameter.name: destroy_fn
parameter.parameter_description: Function used to free the data when the pixbuf's reference count drops to zero, or %NULL if the data should not be freed

parameter.name: destroy_fn_data
parameter.parameter_description: Closure data to pass to the destroy notification function

function.return: A newly-created #GdkPixbuf structure with a reference count of 1.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file
function.description: Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from a file. The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set. Possible errors are in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR and #G_FILE_ERROR domains.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from a file. The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set. Possible errors are in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR and #G_FILE_ERROR domains. The image will be scaled to fit in the requested size, optionally preserving the image's aspect ratio.
When preserving the aspect ratio, a @width of -1 will cause the image to be scaled to the exact given height, and a @height of -1 will cause the image to be scaled to the exact given width. When not preserving aspect ratio, a @width or @height of -1 means to not scale the image at all in that dimension. Negative values for @width and @height are allowed since 2.8.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

parameter.name: preserve_aspect_ratio
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to preserve the image's aspect ratio

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale_utf8
function.description:
Same as gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

parameter.name: preserve_aspect_ratio
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to preserve the image's aspect ratio

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_size
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from a file. The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set. Possible errors are in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR and #G_FILE_ERROR domains.
The image will be scaled to fit in the requested size, preserving the image's aspect ratio. Note that the returned pixbuf may be smaller than @width x @height, if the aspect ratio requires it. To load and image at the requested size, regardless of aspect ratio, use gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_size_utf8
function.description:
Same as gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_size()
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_utf8
function.description: Same as gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file()

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_inline
function.description:
Create a #GdkPixbuf from a flat representation that is suitable for storing as inline data in a program. This is useful if you want to ship a program with images, but don't want to depend on any external files.
gdk-pixbuf ships with a program called [gdk-pixbuf-csource][gdk-pixbuf-csource], which allows for conversion of #GdkPixbufs into such a inline representation. In almost all cases, you should pass the `--raw` option to `gdk-pixbuf-csource`. A sample invocation would be:
|[ gdk-pixbuf-csource --raw --name=myimage_inline myimage.png ]|
For the typical case where the inline pixbuf is read-only static data, you don't need to copy the pixel data unless you intend to write to it, so you can pass %FALSE for @copy_pixels. (If you pass `--rle` to `gdk-pixbuf-csource`, a copy will be made even if @copy_pixels is %FALSE, so using this option is generally a bad idea.)
If you create a pixbuf from const inline data compiled into your program, it's probably safe to ignore errors and disable length checks, since things will always succeed: |[ pixbuf = gdk_pixbuf_new_from_inline (-1, myimage_inline, FALSE, NULL); ]|
For non-const inline data, you could get out of memory. For untrusted inline data located at runtime, you could have corrupt inline data in addition.
Deprecated: 2.32: Use #GResource instead.

parameter.name: data_length
parameter.parameter_description: Length in bytes of the @data argument or -1 to disable length checks

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: Byte data containing a serialized #GdkPixdata structure

parameter.name: copy_pixels
parameter.parameter_description: Whether to copy the pixel data, or use direct pointers @data for the resulting pixbuf

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: #GError return location, may be %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: A newly-created #GdkPixbuf structure with a reference, count of 1, or %NULL if an error occurred.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_resource
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from an resource.
The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: resource_path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of the resource file

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, the image format is not supported, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, the stream contained invalid data, or the operation was cancelled.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_resource_at_scale
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from an resource.
The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set.
The image will be scaled to fit in the requested size, optionally preserving the image's aspect ratio. When preserving the aspect ratio, a @width of -1 will cause the image to be scaled to the exact given height, and a @height of -1 will cause the image to be scaled to the exact given width. When not preserving aspect ratio, a @width or @height of -1 means to not scale the image at all in that dimension.
The stream is not closed.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: resource_path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of the resource file

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

parameter.name: preserve_aspect_ratio
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to preserve the image's aspect ratio

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, the image format is not supported, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, the stream contained invalid data, or the operation was cancelled.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from an input stream.
The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set. The @cancellable can be used to abort the operation from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned. Other possible errors are in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR and %G_IO_ERROR domains.
The stream is not closed.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GInputStream to load the pixbuf from

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, the image format is not supported, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, the stream contained invalid data, or the operation was cancelled.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream_async
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by asynchronously loading an image from an input stream.
For more details see gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream(), which is the synchronous version of this function.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called in the main thread. You can then call gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GInputStream from which to load the pixbuf

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the pixbuf is loaded

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream_at_scale
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from an input stream.
The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set. The @cancellable can be used to abort the operation from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned. Other possible errors are in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR and %G_IO_ERROR domains.
The image will be scaled to fit in the requested size, optionally preserving the image's aspect ratio.
When preserving the aspect ratio, a @width of -1 will cause the image to be scaled to the exact given height, and a @height of -1 will cause the image to be scaled to the exact given width. If both @width and @height are given, this function will behave as if the smaller of the two values is passed as -1.
When not preserving aspect ratio, a @width or @height of -1 means to not scale the image at all in that dimension.
The stream is not closed.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GInputStream to load the pixbuf from

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

parameter.name: preserve_aspect_ratio
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to preserve the image's aspect ratio

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf, or %NULL if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, the image format is not supported, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, the stream contained invalid data, or the operation was cancelled.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream_at_scale_async
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by asynchronously loading an image from an input stream.
For more details see gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream_at_scale(), which is the synchronous version of this function.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called in the main thread. You can then call gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GInputStream from which to load the pixbuf

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

parameter.name: preserve_aspect_ratio
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to preserve the image's aspect ratio

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the pixbuf is loaded

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous pixbuf creation operation started with gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream_async().
Since: 2.24
function.return: a #GdkPixbuf or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_xpm_data
function.description: Creates a new pixbuf by parsing XPM data in memory. This data is commonly the result of including an XPM file into a program's C source.
function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_subpixbuf
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf which represents a sub-region of @src_pixbuf. The new pixbuf shares its pixels with the original pixbuf, so writing to one affects both. The new pixbuf holds a reference to @src_pixbuf, so @src_pixbuf will not be finalized until the new pixbuf is finalized.
Note that if @src_pixbuf is read-only, this function will force it to be mutable.
function.return: a new pixbuf

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_read_pixel_bytes
function.description:
Provides a #GBytes buffer containing the raw pixel data; the data must not be modified. This function allows skipping the implicit copy that must be made if gdk_pixbuf_get_pixels() is called on a read-only pixbuf.
Since: 2.32
function.return: A new reference to a read-only copy of the pixel data. Note that for mutable pixbufs, this function will incur a one-time copy of the pixel data for conversion into the returned #GBytes.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_read_pixels
function.description:
Provides a read-only pointer to the raw pixel data; must not be modified. This function allows skipping the implicit copy that must be made if gdk_pixbuf_get_pixels() is called on a read-only pixbuf.
Since: 2.32
function.return: a read-only pointer to the raw pixel data

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_ref
function.description:
Adds a reference to a pixbuf.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_ref().
function.return: The same as the @pixbuf argument.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_remove_option
function.description:
Remove the key/value pair option attached to a #GdkPixbuf.
Since: 2.36

parameter.name: key
parameter.parameter_description: a nul-terminated string representing the key to remove.

function.return: %TRUE if an option was removed, %FALSE if not.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_rotate_simple
function.description:
Rotates a pixbuf by a multiple of 90 degrees, and returns the result in a new pixbuf.
If @angle is 0, a copy of @src is returned, avoiding any rotation.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the new #GdkPixbuf, or %NULL if not enough memory could be allocated for it.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_saturate_and_pixelate
function.description: Modifies saturation and optionally pixelates @src, placing the result in @dest. @src and @dest may be the same pixbuf with no ill effects. If @saturation is 1.0 then saturation is not changed. If it's less than 1.0, saturation is reduced (the image turns toward grayscale); if greater than 1.0, saturation is increased (the image gets more vivid colors). If @pixelate is %TRUE, then pixels are faded in a checkerboard pattern to create a pixelated image. @src and @dest must have the same image format, size, and rowstride.

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: place to write modified version of @src

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: list of key-value save options, followed by %NULL

function.return: whether an error was set

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save_to_buffer
function.description:
Saves pixbuf to a new buffer in format @type, which is currently "jpeg", "png", "tiff", "ico" or "bmp". This is a convenience function that uses gdk_pixbuf_save_to_callback() to do the real work. Note that the buffer is not nul-terminated and may contain embedded nuls. If @error is set, %FALSE will be returned and @buffer will be set to %NULL. Possible errors include those in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR domain.
See gdk_pixbuf_save() for more details.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: buffer
parameter.parameter_description: location to receive a pointer to the new buffer.

parameter.name: buffer_size
parameter.parameter_description: location to receive the size of the new buffer.

function.return: whether an error was set

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save_to_bufferv
function.description:
Saves pixbuf to a new buffer in format @type, which is currently "jpeg", "tiff", "png", "ico" or "bmp". See gdk_pixbuf_save_to_buffer() for more details.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: buffer
parameter.parameter_description: location to receive a pointer to the new buffer.

parameter.name: buffer_size
parameter.parameter_description: location to receive the size of the new buffer.

function.return: whether an error was set

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save_to_callback
function.description:
Saves pixbuf in format @type by feeding the produced data to a callback. Can be used when you want to store the image to something other than a file, such as an in-memory buffer or a socket. If @error is set, %FALSE will be returned. Possible errors include those in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR domain and whatever the save function generates.
See gdk_pixbuf_save() for more details.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: save_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function that is called to save each block of data that the save routine generates.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the save function.

function.return: whether an error was set

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save_to_callbackv
function.description:
Saves pixbuf to a callback in format @type, which is currently "jpeg", "png", "tiff", "ico" or "bmp". If @error is set, %FALSE will be returned. See gdk_pixbuf_save_to_callback () for more details.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: save_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function that is called to save each block of data that the save routine generates.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the save function.

function.return: whether an error was set

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save_to_stream
function.description:
Saves @pixbuf to an output stream.
Supported file formats are currently "jpeg", "tiff", "png", "ico" or "bmp". See gdk_pixbuf_save_to_buffer() for more details.
The @cancellable can be used to abort the operation from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned. Other possible errors are in the #GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR and %G_IO_ERROR domains.
The stream is not closed.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GOutputStream to save the pixbuf to

function.return: %TRUE if the pixbuf was saved successfully, %FALSE if an error was set.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save_to_stream_async
function.description:
Saves @pixbuf to an output stream asynchronously.
For more details see gdk_pixbuf_save_to_stream(), which is the synchronous version of this function.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called in the main thread. You can then call gdk_pixbuf_save_to_stream_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GOutputStream to which to save the pixbuf

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the pixbuf is saved

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save_to_stream_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous pixbuf save operation started with gdk_pixbuf_save_to_stream_async().
Since: 2.24
function.return: %TRUE if the pixbuf was saved successfully, %FALSE if an error was set.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save_to_streamv
function.description:
Saves @pixbuf to an output stream.
Supported file formats are currently "jpeg", "tiff", "png", "ico" or "bmp". See gdk_pixbuf_save_to_stream() for more details.
Since: 2.36

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GOutputStream to save the pixbuf to

function.return: %TRUE if the pixbuf was saved successfully, %FALSE if an error was set.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_save_to_streamv_async
function.description:
Saves @pixbuf to an output stream asynchronously.
For more details see gdk_pixbuf_save_to_streamv(), which is the synchronous version of this function.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called in the main thread. You can then call gdk_pixbuf_save_to_stream_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.36

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GOutputStream to which to save the pixbuf

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the pixbuf is saved

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_savev
function.description: Saves pixbuf to a file in @type, which is currently "jpeg", "png", "tiff", "ico" or "bmp". If @error is set, %FALSE will be returned. See gdk_pixbuf_save () for more details.
function.return: whether an error was set

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_savev_utf8
function.description: Same as gdk_pixbuf_savev()
function.return: whether an error was set

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_scale
function.description:
Creates a transformation of the source image @src by scaling by @scale_x and @scale_y then translating by @offset_x and @offset_y, then renders the rectangle (@dest_x, @dest_y, @dest_width, @dest_height) of the resulting image onto the destination image replacing the previous contents.
Try to use gdk_pixbuf_scale_simple() first, this function is the industrial-strength power tool you can fall back to if gdk_pixbuf_scale_simple() isn't powerful enough.
If the source rectangle overlaps the destination rectangle on the same pixbuf, it will be overwritten during the scaling which results in rendering artifacts.

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkPixbuf into which to render the results

parameter.name: dest_x
parameter.parameter_description: the left coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_y
parameter.parameter_description: the top coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_width
parameter.parameter_description: the width of the region to render

parameter.name: dest_height
parameter.parameter_description: the height of the region to render

parameter.name: offset_x
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the X direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: offset_y
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the Y direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: scale_x
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the X direction

parameter.name: scale_y
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the Y direction

parameter.name: interp_type
parameter.parameter_description: the interpolation type for the transformation.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_scale_simple
function.description:
Create a new #GdkPixbuf containing a copy of @src scaled to @dest_width x @dest_height. Leaves @src unaffected. @interp_type should be #GDK_INTERP_NEAREST if you want maximum speed (but when scaling down #GDK_INTERP_NEAREST is usually unusably ugly). The default @interp_type should be #GDK_INTERP_BILINEAR which offers reasonable quality and speed.
You can scale a sub-portion of @src by creating a sub-pixbuf pointing into @src; see gdk_pixbuf_new_subpixbuf().
If @dest_width and @dest_height are equal to the @src width and height, a copy of @src is returned, avoiding any scaling.
For more complicated scaling/alpha blending see gdk_pixbuf_scale() and gdk_pixbuf_composite().

parameter.name: interp_type
parameter.parameter_description: the interpolation type for the transformation.

function.return: the new #GdkPixbuf, or %NULL if not enough memory could be allocated for it.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_set_option
function.description:
Attaches a key/value pair as an option to a #GdkPixbuf. If @key already exists in the list of options attached to @pixbuf, the new value is ignored and %FALSE is returned.
Since: 2.2
function.return: %TRUE on success.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_simple_anim_add_frame
function.description:
Adds a new frame to @animation. The @pixbuf must have the dimensions specified when the animation was constructed.
Since: 2.8

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_simple_anim_get_loop
function.description:
Gets whether @animation should loop indefinitely when it reaches the end.
Since: 2.18
function.return: %TRUE if the animation loops forever, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_simple_anim_new
function.description:
Creates a new, empty animation.
Since: 2.8

parameter.name: rate
parameter.parameter_description: the speed of the animation, in frames per second

function.return: a newly allocated #GdkPixbufSimpleAnim

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_simple_anim_set_loop
function.description:
Sets whether @animation should loop indefinitely when it reaches the end.
Since: 2.18

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_unref
function.description:
Removes a reference from a pixbuf.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_unref().

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_version
function.description: Contains the full version of the gdk-pixbuf library as a string. This is the version currently in use by a running program.

function.name: gdk_pixdata_deserialize
function.description:
Deserializes (reconstruct) a #GdkPixdata structure from a byte stream. The byte stream consists of a straightforward writeout of the #GdkPixdata fields in network byte order, plus the @pixel_data bytes the structure points to. The @pixdata contents are reconstructed byte by byte and are checked for validity. This function may fail with %GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR_CORRUPT_IMAGE or %GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR_UNKNOWN_TYPE.
Deprecated: 2.32: Use #GResource instead.

parameter.name: pixdata
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkPixdata structure to be filled in.

parameter.name: stream_length
parameter.parameter_description: length of the stream used for deserialization.

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: stream of bytes containing a serialized #GdkPixdata structure.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: #GError location to indicate failures (maybe %NULL to ignore errors).

function.return: Upon successful deserialization %TRUE is returned, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_pixdata_from_pixbuf
function.description:
Converts a #GdkPixbuf to a #GdkPixdata. If @use_rle is %TRUE, the pixel data is run-length encoded into newly-allocated memory and a pointer to that memory is returned.
Deprecated: 2.32: Use #GResource instead.

parameter.name: use_rle
parameter.parameter_description: whether to use run-length encoding for the pixel data.

function.return: If @use_rle is %TRUE, a pointer to the newly-allocated memory for the run-length encoded pixel data, otherwise %NULL.

function.name: gdk_pixdata_serialize
function.description:
Serializes a #GdkPixdata structure into a byte stream. The byte stream consists of a straightforward writeout of the #GdkPixdata fields in network byte order, plus the @pixel_data bytes the structure points to.
Deprecated: 2.32: Use #GResource instead.

parameter.name: stream_length_p
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the resulting stream length in.

function.return: A newly-allocated string containing the serialized #GdkPixdata structure.

function.name: gdk_pixdata_to_csource
function.description:
Generates C source code suitable for compiling images directly into programs.
gdk-pixbuf ships with a program called [gdk-pixbuf-csource][gdk-pixbuf-csource], which offers a command line interface to this function.
Deprecated: 2.32: Use #GResource instead.

parameter.name: pixdata
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkPixdata to convert to C source.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: used for naming generated data structures or macros.

parameter.name: dump_type
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkPixdataDumpType determining the kind of C source to be generated.

function.return: a newly-allocated string containing the C source form of @pixdata.

function.name: gdk_popup_get_autohide

Set new anchor hints.
The set @anchor_hints determines how @surface will be moved if the anchor points cause it to move off-screen. For example, %GDK_ANCHOR_FLIP_X will replace %GDK_GRAVITY_NORTH_WEST with %GDK_GRAVITY_NORTH_EAST and vice versa if @surface extends beyond the left or right edges of the monitor.

function.name: gdk_popup_present
function.description:
Present @popup after having processed the #GdkPopupLayout rules. If the popup was previously now showing, it will be showed, otherwise it will change position according to @layout.
After calling this function, the result of the layout can be queried using gdk_popup_get_position_x(), gdk_popup_get_position_y(), gdk_surface_get_width(), gdk_surface_get_height(), gdk_popup_get_rect_anchor() and gdk_popup_get_surface_anchor().
Presenting may have fail, for example if it was immediately hidden if the @popup was set to autohide.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained popup width to layout

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained popup height to layout

function.return: %FALSE if it failed to be presented, otherwise %TRUE.

function.name: gdk_rectangle_contains_point
function.description: Returns #TRUE if @rect contains the point described by @x and @y.

function.name: gdk_rectangle_equal
function.description: Checks if the two given rectangles are equal.
function.return: %TRUE if the rectangles are equal.

function.name: gdk_rectangle_intersect
function.description: Calculates the intersection of two rectangles. It is allowed for @dest to be the same as either @src1 or @src2. If the rectangles do not intersect, @dest’s width and height is set to 0 and its x and y values are undefined. If you are only interested in whether the rectangles intersect, but not in the intersecting area itself, pass %NULL for @dest.

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the intersection of @src1 and @src2, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE if the rectangles intersect.

function.name: gdk_rectangle_union
function.description:
Calculates the union of two rectangles. The union of rectangles @src1 and @src2 is the smallest rectangle which includes both @src1 and @src2 within it. It is allowed for @dest to be the same as either @src1 or @src2.
Note that this function does not ignore 'empty' rectangles (ie. with zero width or height).

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the union of @src1 and @src2
