function.description: Frees a #GdkRGBA created with gdk_rgba_copy()

function.name: gdk_rgba_hash
function.description: A hash function suitable for using for a hash table that stores #GdkRGBAs.
function.return: The hash value for @p

function.name: gdk_rgba_is_clear
function.description: Checks if an @rgba value is transparent. That is, drawing with the value would not produce any change.
function.return: %TRUE if the @rgba is clear

function.name: gdk_rgba_is_opaque
function.description: Checks if an @rgba value is opaque. That is, drawing with the value will not retain any results from previous contents.
function.return: %TRUE if the @rgba is opaque

function.name: gdk_rgba_parse
function.description:
Parses a textual representation of a color, filling in the @red, @green, @blue and @alpha fields of the @rgba #GdkRGBA.
The string can be either one of: - A standard name (Taken from the X11 rgb.txt file). - A hexadecimal value in the form “\#rgb”, “\#rrggbb”, “\#rrrgggbbb” or ”\#rrrrggggbbbb” - A RGB color in the form “rgb(r,g,b)” (In this case the color will have full opacity) - A RGBA color in the form “rgba(r,g,b,a)”
Where “r”, “g”, “b” and “a” are respectively the red, green, blue and alpha color values. In the last two cases, “r”, “g”, and “b” are either integers in the range 0 to 255 or percentage values in the range 0% to 100%, and a is a floating point value in the range 0 to 1.
function.return: %TRUE if the parsing succeeded

function.name: gdk_rgba_to_string
function.description:
Returns a textual specification of @rgba in the form `rgb(r,g,b)` or `rgba(r g,b,a)`, where “r”, “g”, “b” and “a” represent the red, green, blue and alpha values respectively. “r”, “g”, and “b” are represented as integers in the range 0 to 255, and “a” is represented as a floating point value in the range 0 to 1.
These string forms are string forms that are supported by the CSS3 colors module, and can be parsed by gdk_rgba_parse().
Note that this string representation may lose some precision, since “r”, “g” and “b” are represented as 8-bit integers. If this is a concern, you should use a different representation.
function.return: A newly allocated text string

function.name: gdk_scroll_event_get_deltas
function.description:
Extracts the scroll deltas of a scroll event.
The deltas will be zero unless the scroll direction is %GDK_SCROLL_SMOOTH.

parameter.name: delta_x
parameter.parameter_description: return location for x scroll delta

parameter.name: delta_y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for y scroll delta

function.name: gdk_scroll_event_get_direction
function.description: Extracts the direction of a scroll event.
function.return: the scroll direction of @event

function.name: gdk_scroll_event_is_stop
function.description:
Check whether a scroll event is a stop scroll event. Scroll sequences with smooth scroll information may provide a stop scroll event once the interaction with the device finishes, e.g. by lifting a finger. This stop scroll event is the signal that a widget may trigger kinetic scrolling based on the current velocity.
Stop scroll events always have a delta of 0/0.
function.return: %TRUE if the event is a scroll stop event

function.name: gdk_seat_get_capabilities
function.description: Returns the capabilities this #GdkSeat currently has.
function.return: the seat capabilities

function.name: gdk_seat_get_display
function.description: Returns the #GdkDisplay this seat belongs to.
function.return: a #GdkDisplay. This object is owned by GTK and must not be freed.

function.name: gdk_seat_get_keyboard
function.description: Returns the master device that routes keyboard events.
function.return: a master #GdkDevice with keyboard capabilities. This object is owned by GTK and must not be freed.

function.name: gdk_seat_get_master_pointers
function.description:
Returns all master pointers with the given capabilities driven by this @seat. On most backends this function will return a list with a single element (meaning that all input devices drive the same onscreen cursor).
In other backends where there can possibly be multiple foci (eg. wayland), this function will return all master #GdkDevices that represent these.
function.return: A list of master pointing devices

function.name: gdk_seat_get_pointer
function.description: Returns the master device that routes pointer events.
function.return: a master #GdkDevice with pointer capabilities. This object is owned by GTK and must not be freed.

function.name: gdk_seat_get_slaves
function.description: Returns the slave devices that match the given capabilities.
function.return: A list of #GdkDevices. The list must be freed with g_list_free(), the elements are owned by GDK and must not be freed.

function.name: gdk_seat_grab
function.description:
Grabs the seat so that all events corresponding to the given @capabilities are passed to this application until the seat is ungrabbed with gdk_seat_ungrab(), or the surface becomes hidden. This overrides any previous grab on the seat by this client.
As a rule of thumb, if a grab is desired over %GDK_SEAT_CAPABILITY_POINTER, all other "pointing" capabilities (eg. %GDK_SEAT_CAPABILITY_TOUCH) should be grabbed too, so the user is able to interact with all of those while the grab holds, you should thus use %GDK_SEAT_CAPABILITY_ALL_POINTING most commonly.
Grabs are used for operations which need complete control over the events corresponding to the given capabilities. For example in GTK this is used for Drag and Drop operations, popup menus and such.
Note that if the event mask of a #GdkSurface has selected both button press and button release events, or touch begin and touch end, then a press event will cause an automatic grab until the button is released, equivalent to a grab on the surface with @owner_events set to %TRUE. This is done because most applications expect to receive paired press and release events.
If you set up anything at the time you take the grab that needs to be cleaned up when the grab ends, you should handle the #GdkEventGrabBroken events that are emitted when the grab ends unvoluntarily.

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkSurface which will own the grab

parameter.name: owner_events
cursor
parameter.parameter_description: the cursor to display while the grab is active. If this is %NULL then the normal cursors are used for @surface and its descendants, and the cursor for @surface is used elsewhere.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: the event that is triggering the grab, or %NULL if none is available.

parameter.name: prepare_func
parameter.parameter_description: function to prepare the surface to be grabbed, it can be %NULL if @surface is visible before this call.

function.return: %GDK_GRAB_SUCCESS if the grab was successful.

function.name: gdk_seat_ungrab
function.description: Releases a grab added through gdk_seat_grab().

function.name: gdk_set_allowed_backends
function.description:
Sets a list of backends that GDK should try to use.
This can be be useful if your application does not work with certain GDK backends.
By default, GDK tries all included backends.
For example, |[<!-- language="C" --> gdk_set_allowed_backends ("wayland,quartz,*"); ]| instructs GDK to try the Wayland backend first, followed by the Quartz backend, and then all others.
If the `GDK_BACKEND` environment variable is set, it determines what backends are tried in what order, while still respecting the set of allowed backends that are specified by this function.
The possible backend names are x11, win32, quartz, broadway, wayland. You can also include a * in the list to try all remaining backends.
This call must happen prior to gdk_display_open(), gtk_init(), or gtk_init_check() in order to take effect.

function.name: gdk_surface_beep
function.description: Emits a short beep associated to @surface in the appropriate display, if supported. Otherwise, emits a short beep on the display just as gdk_display_beep().

function.name: gdk_surface_constrain_size
function.description: Constrains a desired width and height according to a set of geometry hints (such as minimum and maximum size).

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: a mask indicating what portions of @geometry are set

function.name: gdk_surface_create_cairo_context
function.description: Creates a new #GdkCairoContext for rendering on @surface.
function.return: the newly created #GdkCairoContext

function.name: gdk_surface_create_gl_context
function.description:
Creates a new #GdkGLContext matching the framebuffer format to the visual of the #GdkSurface. The context is disconnected from any particular surface or surface.
If the creation of the #GdkGLContext failed, @error will be set.
Before using the returned #GdkGLContext, you will need to call gdk_gl_context_make_current() or gdk_gl_context_realize().
function.return: the newly created #GdkGLContext, or %NULL on error

function.name: gdk_surface_create_similar_surface
function.description:
Create a new surface that is as compatible as possible with the given @surface. For example the new surface will have the same fallback resolution and font options as @surface. Generally, the new surface will also use the same backend as @surface, unless that is not possible for some reason. The type of the returned surface may be examined with cairo_surface_get_type().
Initially the surface contents are all 0 (transparent if contents have transparency, black otherwise.)

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: surface to make new surface similar to

parameter.name: content
parameter.parameter_description: the content for the new surface

function.return:
a pointer to the newly allocated surface. The caller owns the surface and should call cairo_surface_destroy() when done with it.
This function always returns a valid pointer, but it will return a pointer to a “nil” surface if @other is already in an error state or any other error occurs.

function.name: gdk_surface_create_vulkan_context
function.description:
Creates a new #GdkVulkanContext for rendering on @surface.
If the creation of the #GdkVulkanContext failed, @error will be set.
function.return: the newly created #GdkVulkanContext, or %NULL on error

function.name: gdk_surface_destroy
function.description:
Destroys the window system resources associated with @surface and decrements @surface's reference count. The window system resources for all children of @surface are also destroyed, but the children’s reference counts are not decremented.
Note that a surface will not be destroyed automatically when its reference count reaches zero. You must call this function yourself before that happens.

function.name: gdk_surface_freeze_updates
function.description: Temporarily freezes a surface such that it won’t receive expose events. The surface will begin receiving expose events again when gdk_surface_thaw_updates() is called. If gdk_surface_freeze_updates() has been called more than once, gdk_surface_thaw_updates() must be called an equal number of times to begin processing exposes.

function.name: gdk_surface_get_cursor
function.description: Retrieves a #GdkCursor pointer for the cursor currently set on the specified #GdkSurface, or %NULL. If the return value is %NULL then there is no custom cursor set on the specified surface, and it is using the cursor for its parent surface.
function.return: a #GdkCursor, or %NULL. The returned object is owned by the #GdkSurface and should not be unreferenced directly. Use gdk_surface_set_cursor() to unset the cursor of the surface

function.name: gdk_surface_get_device_cursor
function.description: Retrieves a #GdkCursor pointer for the @device currently set on the specified #GdkSurface, or %NULL. If the return value is %NULL then there is no custom cursor set on the specified surface, and it is using the cursor for its parent surface.
function.return: a #GdkCursor, or %NULL. The returned object is owned by the #GdkSurface and should not be unreferenced directly. Use gdk_surface_set_cursor() to unset the cursor of the surface

function.name: gdk_surface_get_device_position
function.description: Obtains the current device position in doubles and modifier state. The position is given in coordinates relative to the upper left corner of @surface.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the X coordinate of @device, or %NULL.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the Y coordinate of @device, or %NULL.

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the modifier mask, or %NULL.

function.name: gdk_surface_get_display
function.description: Gets the #GdkDisplay associated with a #GdkSurface.
function.return: the #GdkDisplay associated with @surface

function.name: gdk_surface_get_frame_clock
function.description: Gets the frame clock for the surface. The frame clock for a surface never changes unless the surface is reparented to a new toplevel surface.

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: surface to get frame clock for

function.return: the frame clock

function.name: gdk_surface_get_height
function.description:
Returns the height of the given @surface.
Surface size is reported in ”application pixels”, not ”device pixels” (see gdk_surface_get_scale_factor()).
function.return: The height of @surface

function.name: gdk_surface_get_mapped
function.description: Checks whether the surface has been mapped (with gdk_surface_show() or gdk_surface_show_unraised()).
function.return: %TRUE if the surface is mapped

function.name: gdk_surface_get_scale_factor
function.description:
Returns the internal scale factor that maps from surface coordiantes to the actual device pixels. On traditional systems this is 1, but on very high density outputs this can be a higher value (often 2).
A higher value means that drawing is automatically scaled up to a higher resolution, so any code doing drawing will automatically look nicer. However, if you are supplying pixel-based data the scale value can be used to determine whether to use a pixel resource with higher resolution data.
The scale of a surface may change during runtime, if this happens a configure event will be sent to the toplevel surface.

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: surface to get scale factor for

function.return: the scale factor

function.name: gdk_surface_get_support_multidevice
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the surface is aware of the existence of multiple devices.
function.return: %TRUE if the surface handles multidevice features.

function.name: gdk_surface_get_width
function.description:
Returns the width of the given @surface.
Surface size is reported in ”application pixels”, not ”device pixels” (see gdk_surface_get_scale_factor()).
function.return: The width of @surface

function.name: gdk_surface_hide
function.description: For toplevel surfaces, withdraws them, so they will no longer be known to the window manager; for all surfaces, unmaps them, so they won’t be displayed. Normally done automatically as part of gtk_widget_hide().

function.name: gdk_surface_invalidate_rect
function.description: A convenience wrapper around gdk_surface_invalidate_region() which invalidates a rectangular region. See gdk_surface_invalidate_region() for details.

parameter.name: rect
parameter.parameter_description: rectangle to invalidate or %NULL to invalidate the whole surface

function.name: gdk_surface_invalidate_region
function.description:
Adds @region to the update area for @surface. The update area is the region that needs to be redrawn, or “dirty region.”
GDK will process all updates whenever the frame clock schedules a redraw, so there’s no need to do forces redraws manually, you just need to invalidate regions that you know should be redrawn.

function.name: gdk_surface_is_destroyed
function.description: Check to see if a surface is destroyed..
function.return: %TRUE if the surface is destroyed

function.name: gdk_surface_new_popup
function.description:
Create a new popup surface.
The surface will be attached to @parent and can be positioned relative to it using gdk_surface_show_popup() or later using gdk_surface_layout_popup().

parameter.name: parent
parameter.parameter_description: the parent surface to attach the surface to

parameter.name: autohide
parameter.parameter_description: whether to hide the surface on outside clicks

function.return: a new #GdkSurface

function.name: gdk_surface_new_temp
function.description: Creates a new temporary surface. The surface will bypass surface management.

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: the display to create the surface on

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: position of the surface on screen

function.return: the new #GdkSurface

function.name: gdk_surface_new_toplevel
function.description: Creates a new toplevel surface.

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: the display to create the surface on

function.return: the new #GdkSurface

function.name: gdk_surface_queue_expose
function.description:
Forces an expose event for @surface to be scheduled.
If the invalid area of @surface is empty, an expose event will still be emitted. Its invalid region will be empty.
This function is useful for implementations that track invalid regions on their own.

function.name: gdk_surface_set_cursor
function.description:
Sets the default mouse pointer for a #GdkSurface.
Note that @cursor must be for the same display as @surface.
Use gdk_cursor_new_from_name() or gdk_cursor_new_from_texture() to create the cursor. To make the cursor invisible, use %GDK_BLANK_CURSOR. Passing %NULL for the @cursor argument to gdk_surface_set_cursor() means that @surface will use the cursor of its parent surface. Most surfaces should use this default.

function.name: gdk_surface_set_device_cursor
function.description: Sets a specific #GdkCursor for a given device when it gets inside @surface. Use gdk_cursor_new_from_name() or gdk_cursor_new_from_texture() to create the cursor. To make the cursor invisible, use %GDK_BLANK_CURSOR. Passing %NULL for the @cursor argument to gdk_surface_set_cursor() means that @surface will use the cursor of its parent surface. Most surfaces should use this default.

function.name: gdk_surface_set_input_region
function.description:
Apply the region to the surface for the purpose of event handling. Mouse events which happen while the pointer position corresponds to an unset bit in the mask will be passed on the surface below @surface.
An input region is typically used with RGBA surfaces. The alpha channel of the surface defines which pixels are invisible and allows for nicely antialiased borders, and the input region controls where the surface is “clickable”.
Use gdk_display_support_input_shapes() to find out if a particular backend supports input regions.

parameter.name: region
parameter.parameter_description: region of surface to be reactive

function.name: gdk_surface_set_opaque_region
function.description:
For optimisation purposes, compositing window managers may like to not draw obscured regions of surfaces, or turn off blending during for these regions. With RGB windows with no transparency, this is just the shape of the window, but with ARGB32 windows, the compositor does not know what regions of the window are transparent or not.
This function only works for toplevel surfaces.
GTK will update this property automatically if the @surface background is opaque, as we know where the opaque regions are. If your surface background is not opaque, please update this property in your #GtkWidgetClass.css_changed() handler.

function.name: gdk_surface_set_shadow_width
function.description:
Newer GTK windows using client-side decorations use extra geometry around their frames for effects like shadows and invisible borders. Window managers that want to maximize windows or snap to edges need to know where the extents of the actual frame lie, so that users don’t feel like windows are snapping against random invisible edges.
Note that this property is automatically updated by GTK, so this function should only be used by applications which do not use GTK to create toplevel surfaces.

function.name: gdk_surface_set_support_multidevice
function.description:
This function will enable multidevice features in @surface.
Multidevice aware surfaces will need to handle properly multiple, per device enter/leave events, device grabs and grab ownerships.

function.name: gdk_surface_thaw_updates
function.description: Thaws a surface frozen with gdk_surface_freeze_updates(). Note that this will not necessarily schedule updates if the surface freeze count reaches zero.

function.name: gdk_surface_translate_coordinates
function.description:
Translates the given coordinates from being relative to the @from surface to being relative to the @to surface.
Note that this only works if @to and @from are popups or transient-for to the same toplevel (directly or indirectly).
function.return: %TRUE if the coordinates were successfully translated

function.name: gdk_texture_download
function.description:
Downloads the @texture into local memory. This may be an expensive operation, as the actual texture data may reside on a GPU or on a remote display server.
The data format of the downloaded data is equivalent to %CAIRO_FORMAT_ARGB32, so every downloaded pixel requires 4 bytes of memory.
Downloading a texture into a Cairo image surface: |[<!-- language="C" --> surface = cairo_image_surface_create (CAIRO_FORMAT_ARGB32, gdk_texture_get_width (texture), gdk_texture_get_height (texture)); gdk_texture_download (texture, cairo_image_surface_get_data (surface), cairo_image_surface_get_stride (surface)); cairo_surface_mark_dirty (surface); ]|

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to enough memory to be filled with the downloaded data of @texture

function.name: gdk_texture_get_height
function.description: Returns the height of the @texture.
function.return: the height of the #GdkTexture

function.name: gdk_texture_get_width
function.description: Returns the width of @texture.
function.return: the width of the #GdkTexture

function.name: gdk_texture_new_for_pixbuf
function.description: Creates a new texture object representing the GdkPixbuf.
function.return: a new #GdkTexture

function.name: gdk_texture_new_for_surface
function.description: Creates a new texture object representing the surface. @surface must be an image surface with format CAIRO_FORMAT_ARGB32.
function.return: a new #GdkTexture

function.name: gdk_texture_new_from_file
function.description: Creates a new texture by loading an image from a file. The file format is detected automatically. If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set.
function.return: A newly-created #GdkTexture or %NULL if an error occured.

function.name: gdk_texture_new_from_resource
function.description:
Creates a new texture by loading an image from a resource. The file format is detected automatically.
It is a fatal error if @resource_path does not specify a valid image resource and the program will abort if that happens. If you are unsure about the validity of a resource, use gdk_texture_new_from_file() to load it.

parameter.name: resource_path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of the resource file

function.return: A newly-created texture

function.name: gdk_texture_save_to_png
function.description:
Store the given @texture to the @filename as a PNG file.
This is a utility function intended for debugging and testing. If you want more control over formats, proper error handling or want to store to a #GFile or other location, you might want to look into using the gdk-pixbuf library.
function.return: %TRUE if saving succeeded, %FALSE on failure.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_begin_move
function.description: Begins an interactive move operation (for a toplevel surface). You might use this function to implement draggable titlebars.

parameter.name: device
parameter.parameter_description: the device used for the operation

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the button being used to drag, or 0 for a keyboard-initiated drag

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: surface X coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: surface Y coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: timestamp of mouse click that began the drag

function.name: gdk_toplevel_begin_resize
function.description: Begins an interactive resize operation (for a toplevel surface). You might use this function to implement a “window resize grip.”

parameter.name: edge
parameter.parameter_description: the edge or corner from which the drag is started

parameter.name: device
parameter.parameter_description: the device used for the operation

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the button being used to drag, or 0 for a keyboard-initiated drag

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: surface X coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: surface Y coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: timestamp of mouse click that began the drag (use gdk_event_get_time())

function.name: gdk_toplevel_focus
function.description:
Sets keyboard focus to @surface.
In most cases, gtk_window_present_with_time() should be used on a #GtkWindow, rather than calling this function.

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: timestamp of the event triggering the surface focus

function.name: gdk_toplevel_get_state
function.description: Gets the bitwise OR of the currently active surface state flags, from the #GdkSurfaceState enumeration.
function.return: surface state bitfield

function.name: gdk_toplevel_inhibit_system_shortcuts
function.description:
Requests that the @toplevel inhibit the system shortcuts, asking the desktop environment/windowing system to let all keyboard events reach the surface, as long as it is focused, instead of triggering system actions.
If granted, the rerouting remains active until the default shortcuts processing is restored with gdk_toplevel_restore_system_shortcuts(), or the request is revoked by the desktop enviroment, windowing system or the user.
A typical use case for this API is remote desktop or virtual machine viewers which need to inhibit the default system keyboard shortcuts so that the remote session or virtual host gets those instead of the local environment.
The windowing system or desktop environment may ask the user to grant or deny the request or even choose to ignore the request entirely.
The caller can be notified whenever the request is granted or revoked by listening to the GdkToplevel::shortcuts-inhibited property.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkEvent that is triggering the inhibit request, or %NULL if none is available.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_copy
function.description: Create a new #GdkToplevelLayout and copy the contents of @layout into it.
function.return: a copy of @layout.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_equal
function.description: Check whether @layout and @other has identical layout properties.
function.return: %TRUE if @layout and @other have identical layout properties, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_fullscreen
function.description: Returns whether the layout should cause the surface to be fullscreen when presented.
function.return: %TRUE if @layout is fullscreen

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_fullscreen_monitor
function.description: Returns the monitor that the layout is fullscreening the surface on.
function.return: the monitor on which @layout fullscreens

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_maximized
function.description: Returns whether the layout should present the surface as maximized.
function.return: %TRUE if the layout is maximized

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_min_height
function.description: Returns the minimum height of the given layout.
function.return: the minimum height of @layout

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_min_width
function.description: Returns the minimum width of the given layout.
function.return: the minimum width of @layout

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_resizable
function.description: Returns whether the layout should allow the user to resize the surface.
function.return: %TRUE if the layout is resizable

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_new
function.description:
Create a toplevel layout description.
Used together with gdk_toplevel_present() to describe how a toplevel surface should be placed and behave on-screen.
The size is in ”application pixels”, not ”device pixels” (see gdk_surface_get_scale_factor()).

parameter.name: min_width
parameter.parameter_description: the minimum width for the layout

parameter.name: min_height
parameter.parameter_description: the minimum height for the layout

function.return: newly created instance of #GdkToplevelLayout

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count of @layout.
function.return: the same @layout

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_set_fullscreen
function.description: Sets whether the layout should cause the surface to be fullscreen when presented.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_set_maximized
function.description: Sets whether the layout should cause the surface to be maximized when presented.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_set_resizable
function.description: Sets whether the layout should allow the user to resize the surface after it has been presented.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count of @layout.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_lower
function.description:
Asks to lower the @toplevel below other windows.
The windowing system may choose to ignore the request.
function.return: %TRUE if the surface was lowered

function.name: gdk_toplevel_minimize
function.description:
Asks to minimize the @toplevel.
The windowing system may choose to ignore the request.
function.return: %TRUE if the surface was minimized

function.name: gdk_toplevel_present
function.description:
Present @toplevel after having processed the #GdkToplevelLayout rules. If the toplevel was previously now showing, it will be showed, otherwise it will change layout according to @layout.
Presenting may fail.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained toplevel width to layout

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained toplevel height to layout

function.return: %FALSE if @toplevel failed to be presented, otherwise %TRUE.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_restore_system_shortcuts
function.description: Restore default system keyboard shortcuts which were previously requested to be inhibited by gdk_toplevel_inhibit_system_shortcuts().

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_decorated
function.description: Setting @decorated to %FALSE hints the desktop environment that the surface has its own, client-side decorations and does not need to have window decorations added.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_deletable
function.description: Setting @deletable to %TRUE hints the desktop environment that it should offer the user a way to close the surface.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_icon_list
function.description:
Sets a list of icons for the surface.
One of these will be used to represent the surface in iconic form. The icon may be shown in window lists or task bars. Which icon size is shown depends on the window manager. The window manager can scale the icon but setting several size icons can give better image quality.
Note that some platforms don't support surface icons.

parameter.name: surfaces
parameter.parameter_description: A list of textures to use as icon, of different sizes

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_modal
function.description:
The application can use this hint to tell the window manager that a certain surface has modal behaviour. The window manager can use this information to handle modal surfaces in a special way.
You should only use this on surfaces for which you have previously called gdk_toplevel_set_transient_for().

parameter.name: modal
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the surface is modal, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_startup_id
function.description: When using GTK, typically you should use gtk_window_set_startup_id() instead of this low-level function.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_title
function.description: Sets the title of a toplevel surface, to be displayed in the titlebar, in lists of windows, etc.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_transient_for
function.description:
Indicates to the window manager that @surface is a transient dialog associated with the application surface @parent. This allows the window manager to do things like center @surface on @parent and keep @surface above @parent.
See gtk_window_set_transient_for() if you’re using #GtkWindow or #GtkDialog.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_show_window_menu
function.description:
Asks the windowing system to show the window menu.
The window menu is the menu shown when right-clicking the titlebar on traditional windows managed by the window manager. This is useful for windows using client-side decorations, activating it with a right-click on the window decorations.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: a #GdkEvent to show the menu for

function.return: %TRUE if the window menu was shown and %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_supports_edge_constraints
function.description: Returns whether the desktop environment supports tiled window states.
function.return: %TRUE if the desktop environment supports tiled window states

function.name: gdk_touch_event_get_emulating_pointer
function.description: Extracts whether a touch event is emulating a pointer event.
function.return: %TRUE if @event is emulating

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_deltas
function.description: Extracts delta information from a touchpad event.

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_gesture_phase
function.description: Extracts the touchpad gesture phase from a touchpad event.
function.return: the gesture phase of @event

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_n_fingers
function.description: Extracts the number of fingers from a touchpad event.
function.return: the number of fingers for @event

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_pinch_angle_delta
function.description: Extracts the angle delta from a touchpad pinch event.
function.return: the angle delta of @event

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_pinch_scale
function.description: Extracts the scale from a touchpad pinch event.
function.return: the scale of @event

function.name: gdk_unicode_to_keyval
function.description: Convert from a ISO10646 character to a key symbol.
function.return: the corresponding GDK key symbol, if one exists. or, if there is no corresponding symbol, wc | 0x01000000

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_device
function.description: Gets the Vulkan device that this context is using.
function.return: the VkDevice

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_draw_index
function.description:
Gets the index of the image that is currently being drawn.
This function can only be used between gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() and gdk_draw_context_end_frame() calls.
function.return: the index of the images that is being drawn

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_draw_semaphore
function.description:
Gets the Vulkan semaphore that protects access to the image that is currently being drawn.
This function can only be used between gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() and gdk_draw_context_end_frame() calls.
function.return: the VkSemaphore

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_image
function.description: Gets the image with index @id that this context is using.

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the image to return

function.return: the VkImage

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_image_format
function.description: Gets the image format that this context is using.
function.return: the VkFormat

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_instance
function.description: Gets the Vulkan instance that is associated with @context.
function.return: the VkInstance

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_n_images
function.description: Gets the number of images that this context is using in its swap chain.
function.return: the number of images

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_physical_device
function.description: Gets the Vulkan physical device that this context is using.
function.return: the VkPhysicalDevice

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_queue
function.description: Gets the Vulkan queue that this context is using.
function.return: the VkQueue

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_queue_family_index
function.description: Gets the family index for the queue that this context is using. See vkGetPhysicalDeviceQueueFamilyProperties().
function.return: the index
